If anyone can translate this we will know more:Der VS > 402 Double Extra ist die logische Weiterentwicklung des sehr beliebten VS > 401.
Hierzu wurde das sehr griffige, elastische Obergummi mit einem modernen, etwas härteren Offensivschwamm kombiniert.
Durch diese neuartige Schwamm-Obergummi-Kombination ist dieser High Energy Tension-Belag die ideale Waffe für alle spinorientierten Allrounder.

Das extrem griffige und flexible Obergummi greift den Ball förmlich und sorgt dadurch für eine fantastische Rotationsentwicklung, sowohl bei eigenen Topspinbällen als auch bei stark unterschnittenen Abwehrbällen.
Der optimierte Offensivschwamm des VS > 402 Double Extra bewirkt im Vergleich zum VS > 401 noch mehr Dynamik, was besonders bei eigenen Topspinbällen ein großer Vorteil ist.
Trotz dieses zusätzlichen Tempogewinns lassen sich auch weiterhin sehr kontrollierte und gleichzeitig gefährliche Unterschnittvarianten erzeugen.
I keep the exact translation for the german native speakers, but in short: it's the successor of the Victas VS > 401.
The sponge is harder than the one of the 401 and the topsheet is very grippy and very flexible.
It's more dynamic in topspin play, while keeping backspin play very controlled and strong.I might consider this rubber.
The Victas VS>402 looks very interesting  If it's anywhere as good as the 401 which I'm using on my FH of one of my Re-Impact Barath's it will be impressive.
Nice summary.
A more dynamic VS>401 for allround spin oriented play.I also read it will be in 1,8, 2,0 and 2,3 mm.
The VS>402 Double Extra is the logical development of the very popular VS>401.
Therefore the very grippy and elastic topsheet was combined with a modern and a little bit harder offensive sponge.

Due to this new sponge-topsheet combination this High Energy Tension-rubber is the weapon of choice for spinoriented allrounders.The extream grippy and flexible topsheet litterally grips the ball and creates fantastic spin, on own topspin strokes as well as on heavy underspin chops.
The optimized offensive sponge of the VS>402 Double Extra gives in relation to the VS>401 even more dynamic, wich is a advantage especially on topspin strokes.

But despite the gain in speed, you can still play very controlled and dangerous backspin balls.So from what i read, it is the VS>401 topsheet with a harder sponge, probably a ESN sponge with more Tension then the VS>401 had.
Could be for players who thougt the VS>401 to slow, but Tenergy, Evolution, Bluefire,... to fast.
Maybe an option for players with chinese rubbers on their forehand that look for more dynamic.
Kind Regards
The sponge on the 401 is already quite firm, so I'm not sure if I'd like it harder.
The 401 topsheet is great though, soft and very elastic and VERY spinny!
Thanx.
I saw it at contra.de in these thicknesses, indeed.
For you there might be this:The VS>402 Limber ist the softest version of the grippy Victas VS-Series.
The grippy and elastic Topsheet is combined with the catapultic(bouncy) Limber-offensive sponge, which created a whole new feeling(feedback).

The new 40°-Sponge gives this High Energy Tension rubber an incredible control in the offensive game as well as a great sound.With the very grippy topsheet you can put pressure onto your opponent with a dangerous serve/return game and high rotation spins.
This unique sponge-topsheet-combination gives a new dimension of fun into a diverse Allround game.
Kind Regards

The 401 is fairly heavy (similar to something like T05), and the sponge quite firm.
However the sponge is powerful, far more powerful than any Chinese rubber, including Hurricane.

When you brush the ball mainly with the topsheet, it's extremly spinny and not too disimilar to a Chinese rubber, but once you dig the ball into the sponge it's powerful and fast, similar to something like T05.Hurricane topsheet is harder, so you'll get considerable less spin for slow brush loops, but similar spin at medium to fast loops.The 401 is also really good for blocking.
My blocking has always been a weakness, but it's really improved since I changed from 999 turbo to 401.
The 401 is much less sensitive to spin compared to most Chinese rubbers, and feels very direct and accurate.
I suspect the really short pimples (on the inside) provide this.
I think I'm reading contradicting things about the sponge of 402 Double Extra.
The description from early in this thread said 402 would be like 401 with a harder, more offensive sponge.

Anybody know?
I think it was a misleading translation that caused a misunderstanding.
According to Victas website vs 401 is at 57, vs 402 double extra at 50 and Limber at 40 degrees.

As I have given the translation, maybe I can clarify.In the german description from Victas, they have said: "Hierzu wurde das sehr griffige, elastische Obergummi mit einem modernen, etwas härteren Offensivschwamm kombiniert."
which I have translated as " Therefore the very grippy and elastic topsheet was combined with a modern and a little bit harder offensive sponge.
"I think the problam was the "...a modern and a little bit harder..." which leads to the understandig, that the sponge is in relation to the old sponge modern and a little bit harder.
But the meaning seems to be, that the sponge is a modern, a bit harder offensive sponge, which is in relation to the class of offensive sponges.
But to be honest, I also understood it like the new sponge would be harder then the old one.
Kind Regards

The new Victas 402 DE caught my attention when I decided to revert to inverted rubber on my BH, and I obtained a 1.8 red.
It arrived three days ago, and I tried on my Re impact Barrath and Andro Supreme Kinetic all+.
As it was only my first two sessions of about six hours playing, my opinion most probly isn't objective enough.
Also bear in mind my description below refer to my BH strokes only.
It comprises of, as described in this thread, a firm but not too hard sponge.
The top sheet is soft and elastic.
It proves to be an excellent device in many departments of my style of game.
Speed and control.
Normally these elements are contradicting to one another.
But his rubber provides fast catapult effect, and the ball can be returned in great preciseness.
IMO, this is achieved by the good combination of sponge and top sheet.
I always have difficulties with Barath in blocking.
No problem at all with Vic >402 DE on.
Those attacks that usually are blocked high away by me are now nicely done.
Real satisfaction.
If my blocks are hit back to me with more power, my follow up blocks explode like mighty cannon and with greater speed, as the ball just bounces back with the incoming force.

Leaving my opponent only to watch the ball fly pass him(a district level experienced player).In power brush looping from mid distance, the trajactory is medium flat and packed with SPEED, POWER AND SPINNNNNNNNNNNN!
My mates are surprised at the change in this aspect.Opening drive is the only area where I encountered shortcoming of this rubber, probly due to my skill.
I find it difficult to open up a serve via BH driving.
If I side swope or light hit, the result are much better.Perhaps the best area of this rubber is hitting.
It is like effortless, even under pressure.
You may hit hard and the rubber releases that similar great power with speed.
Or you just lazily hit, and the ball can be placed anywhere according to your wish.
My, it is real joy!I tried to chop back hard looping balls.
Almost all my chops go back are low, straight and easily done.
They are not that deadly as I chop with lp though.I don't have the opportunity to play more with it.
But I hope my little experience with this rubber may provide sort of reference to those interested.

I had no problem gluing VS401 to a sealed blade, using Donic formula glue.
As I play more games with 402DE, the more I discovered its strength in various perspectives.This rubber "covered up" my weakness in TT.
Sluggishness sets into my movement as my physical strength dwindles.
This was most obvious since a year ago.
One of my TT mates is very good in changing his wrist work at the last second.
Returning my first FH lp chopping against his hard FH looping to my FH, then he would, during his second or third looping, opens his blade and loop straight down to my BH.
I wasn't able to move in in time for this.
I tend to hit/block them long at that last moment.
402 DE makes thing easier for me.
Somehow I am able to block the ball to his BH pressuring him to either block off table or a weak return for me hitting.
I know it is not my game has improved, because this change comes soon after I started playing 402 DE.
The 401 blocks really well, and seems quite accurate.
Sounds like the 402 shares this characteristics.
If it does not have gluing problem and blocks well, hmmm it should be a good rubber for player like me.
Thank you for your opinion.

Sorry fazer227 to take so long to reply but have only just read your query.

Using the Barath I prefer the Victas > 401 but I’m now using the Re-Impact Smart & have tried the Victas > 401 which is good but I find the Victas > 402 limber better, I'm very impressed with this set up (more so than the Barath), more control & spin with great power when required with this blade/rubber combination.
Let me start this off by saying, yes.
This makes a world of difference.
No I'm not referring to the price, the adequacy, or the effectiveness.
But as far as differences go, Omega V pro vs Tenergy 05 are about as different as you can get in my opinion.

Also, I've never used T64 extensively, so I can't compare it to Omega V Tour.By the way, before I can make any advice or comments I give on these rubbers helpful to you, I'll have to know your approximate USATT rating.
Anyway, like I've said and will say.
It all depends on your game.
The Tenergy 05 rubber is something I'll recommend to few people, in spite of the fact that it's one of the best rubbers I've ever used.
Here's why: -It's very sensitive to spin; the serves are great, but good iuck receiving spin you're unsure about.
To continue on that: -It's incredibly bouncy in the short game.
So much so that if you dont absolutely know how to receive serves at your own rating level, T05 will doom you before you get your chance to fatally loop drive them off the table.

-The throw is so high, that if you don't know what you're doing, you will do either A) always loop long off the table on power loops, or B) get used to adjusting your racket angle so closed for powerloops that any time you have to loop a basic dead ball you'll throw it right into the net.
The pros of T05 however are: -Extreme, serious looping ability!
Let me stress, you must know how to loop.
When I say loop, I don't mean "how to topspin".
I mean, know how to loop any variant of underspin, dead ball, or counterdrive any level of topspin.
But if you're cut out to do that, I'll be damned if I can personally find a better rubber for sheer looping prowess.
-Your serves will simply murder folks (who are at least 100 lower than your rating.
If you seriously think your serves keep your rating 100 or 200 points higher than the rest of your game, that really means that you need to work more on your game, not that you're a talented server.
Believe me, I've learned this the hard way, moving up the ranks).

HOWEVER, even against folks you're on equal footing with, the extra spin on serves can be a bonus GIVEN THAT YOU KNOW how to vary subtly between no spin, slight spin, slightly more spin, and heavy spin.
coming to Omega V pro: first let me say, what an amazing rubber.
Its the PERFECT sponge hardness if you ask me (a little harder than Tenergy) yet more than welcomely less bouncy.

I know I may get flamed for saying this, but it's sliightly comparable to Chinese rubbers in that the blocks and short game are sloow, yet power loops/loop drives/counter drives go at a bullet pace provided you have the arm strength.
In my opinion much better for opening loop followed by hard drive, as compared to Tenergy.

(the hugest difference as compared to Chinese rubbers is obviously is that it doesn't have the sheer tack of Chinese rubbers; that in mind, the throw angle will not increase with arm speed; I need not tell you that Euro/Jap rubbers and Chinese rubbers require an entirely different mentality and stroke.
Right?)

Reasons why I would not recommend it to folks: When I say this, I say this for real: Do not get a remotely hard sponged rubber if you aren't prepared to use it (keep in mind, this is much less hard than good Chinese rubbers!)
Trust me; I'm in my physical prime being a healthy 26 year old man who works out regularly.
That said, it took me 2 years of hard practice, to be able to comprehend why hard sponged rubbers are better.
They are non-ideal for learning stroke, being that they're less forgiving.
but if you are confident enough in your stroke, the harder sponges help reward your confidence with greater spin and forward force.
They don't reward hesitation!
In fact, they punish it.

HOWEVER: In this particular, rarity of a case only applicable to a comparison with T05, the Omega V pro is still more controllable, given that it's much deader and less bouncy on soft shots, and moreover has a less volatile topsheet (by which I mean remarkably spin sensitive) and will allow you to slightly misread the amount of spin but still get a weak return to land on the table.
Reasons why I would recommend the Omega V pro: -The hard sponge mixed with CONFIDENT loop drives; it'll turn you into a murderer.
-Should I mention the confidence again?
CRUCIAL.
If you're confident, this won't stop you.
- If you have no problems lifting underspin.
I remember starting off with Baracuda or T05 and thinking nothing of underspin.
Okay guys; yeah you have to start under the table with this rubber.

But hey, get those feet moving and live a little, and you'll find yourself getting used to the lower throw vs underspin while at the same time pounding on those loops and drives from your opponents; with ease.
If you aren't at least over 1800 USATT, hoenstly don't bother with this.
Try a softer rubber to learn the stroke first.
(Unless you attempt to play with the full chinese arm stroke, in which case I can't help you there) - Serving is B****ing!
Well.. not as great as T05 BUT: my left handed He Zhi Wen style fast heavy side/topspin to the midrange edge murders folk, and my wristy side/backspin fools 2000+ players into the net.
Yeah; you'll get some spin out of this.
-Counterlooping: I must say, this rivals if not slightly (but hey, I only mean slightly) exceeds T05 at this.
With T05, if you really, really, and I mean absotively posolutely know what you're doing, you'll make some killer counterloops.

But with the Omega V pro, all it takes is the rash mind of a relatively young person combined with some intellect for spin, and the will to destroy, and you'll be banging your opponents loops down into oblivion.
The comparative lack of bounciness along with the relative hardness of the sponge plays in big there.
I hope I've covered something with that?
Let me know if I was incomplete in any area and I'll try to supplement.

Just a remark about these types of threads in general.
Small tweaks are not going to make any tangible difference unless you're either high level, or have some technical flaw* in which case it reveals another type of problem.
A softer sponge is maybe 5-10% difference.
I seriously doubt that a control issue anyone can readily observe and willing to admit is a case of the former, and for the latter a meager 5-10% isn't going to matter.
Sure a 5-10% slower tenergy is going to be better control, but anything 5-10% slower is better control, and anything 20% slower is even better control.

If we're being technical here, with something like a very slow Koji Matsushita defensive it's possible (and advisable) to open the blade a bit & more fwd stroked topspins so a softer sponge is not going to encourage faster swings useful to attacking from longer range.
People usually use softer sponge on more upward traditional euro loops (enables a bit higher throw with low-grip rubbers to make the methodology less flawed).

Then again the OP might have that kind of stroke but who knows.edit:* A common example of this are players overdrilled on a certain stroke, esp power strokes, know to how to perform it by rote (going through the motions) but not by feel.
This result in a lack of understanding and inflexibility as a result.

If they get used to doing it with a certain type of rubber (like a T05 before it deadens) then whatever happens along that restores or "enhances" the original parameters is going get full marks and anything different that requires some adjustment gets marks off.
This has nothing to do with equipment but rather themselves.

I played the maxxx 500 on the flame extreme.The flame extreme is comparable to the BTY Amultart in speed.
(Very,very fast)Maxxx500 has a higher arc relative to tenergy 64.It generates huge amounts of rotation and looping underspin is easy.

However, hitting and punching on backhand (which is what i personally do) is not as good as it would be with rhyzm.Essentially, rhyzm and Maxxx 500 are brother and sister rubbers; rhyzm hits and maxxx 500 spins.Both do generate good pace, however.What specific tensor do you want me to compare it to?
I've been using Maxx 400 and Rhyzm 425 for the past few weeks - testing BH rubbers on two Rossi Emotion blades.
I have to agree with the above comparison - Rhyzm is solid, punchy, stable.
Maxx is elastic, highly spinny, big arc, more sensitive to incoming spin.
I can produce really good spin from BH loops with Maxx, but it feels less precise than Rhyzm when blocking, hitting.
I prefer Rhyzm at this stage.
Incidentally, how alike (or non-alike) are Tensors in general?
Is there a large range in properties?
Any specially for chopping, for instance?
Or blocking, or whatever?
Or are they all slight variations on the same theme?Iskandar
In any given generation, there are outliers, and there are variations on the same theme.
There are also some throwbacks to older generations.
It's a mixed bag.For example, the Bluefire M series, the original Rasant, Evolution, Vega Japan rubbers were all quite similar (noticeable that these all use a smelly factory booster).
Victas 401 was very different though.
Bluefire JP arrived.
JP03 was very similar to Rasant Powersponge.

I didn't try Rasant Turbo, but I guess it might share a lot with JP01.Then I tried Xiom Omega V, which is similar to Rasant Grip.And then Joola Maxx arrived, and that smells of the same booster that the original Bluefire M series used, and I was surprised that this was still being used (Bluefire M used it, but JP didn't).
It could be that Maxx uses a new-gen topsheet but old-gen sponge I suppose.So, there are some tensors which feel specialised (the Victas ones are good examples, IMO.
Xiom Tau is tacky, which isn't the norm).
But mostly they are general euro offensive rubbers.
You pick based on sponge hardness, speed, throw, topsheet grip and elasticity based on your needs.

Generally H2 topsheet is tackier than the H2 Neo.
The Neo Sponge is softer, lighter and more lively.
Both would be suited to close-in play, but the Neo version is faster and much easier to generate pace with.

If I got this right, NEO is for the post speed glue era.

There's a thread here discussing the difference between Hurricane 3 and Hurricane 3 Neoviewtopic.php?f=44&t=13837&p=149724&hilit=hurricane+3+neo+video#p149724I can't answer about the blue sponge version though, so will leave that to others who've tried both.
the neo rubbers are pre tuned and are quicker than their standard brothers.
they also feel harder.as for the blue sponge the are not pretuned but over all the blue sponge is somewhat better than the standard sponge.. to some people it has a better feel and plays alot better
Tuning on the NEO is debatable, if there is any it's so weak that it may as well not be there.
Neo is softer than regular H3, not harder.
The Regular Hurricane III is much tackier than the Neo H3.
The #21 sponge version is also a little less tacky but not as noticable.
The H3 commercial is rock hard.
The #21 is medium hard the Neo is somewhere in between.
However alot of H3 sheets out there are left over from the gluing days and those are quite a bit softer due to the glue effect but the density of the rubber remains so its pretty nice to play.
If you have one of those laying around cherish it forever.
H3 commercial is hard and needs regular speed gluing before play to 'soften' it up a little.
Unusable without speed gluing.
H3 commercial NEO is pre-tuned but loses its properties in about 1-2weeks after it is removed from the vacuum packaging.
It is vacuum packed for a reason.
Need speed glue afterall.
H3 blue sponge #20 provincial is relatively softer and lighter than commercial.
It also comes in NEO version.
I have tried the 39 and 40 degree NEO versions.
Fantastic even without speed glue, well, not totally, reglue once a month.
The China national team uses the blue sponge version.
You will see it if you scrutinize the match broadcasts.
However, what they are using is not commercially available.
Wouldn't the degree of tackiness be a function of the topsheet, and aren't the H3 topsheets all the same?Iskandar
They are supposed to, since DHS would had only one of them ITTF approved, but but they are definitely different, and it's more than variation between sheets.
Actually, if you think about it, how would they enforce this, even if they wanted to?Iskandar
The NEO rubbers are factory tuned, but the tuning is moderate.
If you would like a speed glue feeling, you might need more booster.
About hardness: the hardness of NEO rubbers are measured after tuning.
Therefore, the hardness mark means the same hardness in your hand as original Hurricane or Skyline rubbers.
The reason why you feel they are different is because the tuned sponge becomes more flexible.

Another point is, since tuning softens the sponge, when the booster goes away in about 3 weeks' time, the sponge will be about 1 degree harder than the marked value.By the way, we have noticed that DHS has slightly reduced the tackiness of the hurricane topsheet for slightly more speed to cope with the glue ban.Provincial and national DHS rubbers are known to at least have more even hardness across the entire sponge area.
Whether their sponges have the same composition and crafting technique as the commercial version remains controversy.

Yes this is no surprise  Max sponge, especially in a softer rubber like Rakza 7 soft allows the ball to sink in a lot more, this means speed is absorbed more for blocking and the ball sinks in more and allows a longer dwell time, while this is a bit slower it definitely gives you the ability to produce more spin on the ball and usually create a bit higher arc on the ball.
mmm...very, very interesting, since I recently let my short pips to play again with soft inverted rubbers... About these observations, I'll try to check with my Genius sound 2.0 and max...
@PRW,It depends on how you measure control.
For example, you mentioned "touch drop shots were more difficult".

Doesn't that mean it is harder to control on max where fine touches are required?Sorry and without being disrespectful, but I don't exactly agree with the slight loss of speed impression when moving from a 2mm to max inverted rubber.

If anything, a thicker sponge inverted rubber should allow you to get more speed from your shot, regardless of the softness of the sponge:1) The key to it is, how the ball is hit - basically technique, standing position and timing.2) And secondly, how are you measuring speed - is it the speed in which the ball stays on the table, or is it the speed in which the ball travels regardless where the ball ends up.
If it is measured by the former then you have to look at how you are hitting the ball - technique and sharpness issues.

Of course, there are physics boundaries where the shot will not land on the table at any faster speed.Slightly off the topic, but please do not forget the hidden danger in using max thickness sponge too early.

This being, it may inhibit or stagnate development - as it is far easier to develop better techniques with lesser equipment because you have to make up for the shortcomings; or another way of looking at it, the max thickness is sometimes too helpful such that you forget to develop your skills as you become too reliant on equipment.

This includes a blade that is too good or fast - for example it is so much easier for me to block with my Acoustic Carbon blade vs say my Swifter or Legato 5A, yet I learn much more if I stick to my Swifter or Legato 5A.
The only equipment which I think you should aim for the best are a good pair of shoes (injury prevention and movement development) and comfortable clothing.

On loops, as I can trust the rubber to allow the ball to sink in more, I can actually go faster, as the arc is higher.1.

See above replies!Agree - but I am in my 50's, have been playing a very long time (with a 25 year break in the middle) and as I say, was very happy with 2mm... getting more control to me is a good thing, I wasn't looking for more speed.
I have no illusions that I have to play with max because "everyone else does" or "it's the best" - I was just genuinely surprised at the fact that my control improved, opposite to what I expected.
I agree though, for people starting out, or developing strokes, max could hinder development.
I always enjoy reading TT 11 comments on equip., they are very good ...
Personally I prefer the max thickness in rubbers.

What I've found is that the thinner 1.9-2.0 ones don't seem to perform as well as their thicker counterparts as they age with the thinner ones more susceptible to going hard.On some makes a max rubber can be hard to control compared to a thinner version e.g.
a T05.

For lifting under spin i always found a thicker one easier to use but in a counter rally it can go off the rails.After replacing a club mates tibhar defensive BH rubber with a 2.1 EL-P his setup weight jumped from a nicely balanced 168 grams to a not so nice 185 grams.

I had recommended a 1.9 to keep the weight under wraps but he wanted a new rubber on as soon as possible.If the EL-p is anything like the R7S in the difference in weight between the max & the 2.0 it would / could have saved himself those all important extra 3 grams.
Sometimes you have to opt for the thinner size just to keep the bat balanced.
He wouldn't be a happy bunny when he gets his bat tonight !
Thanks longball, we try and do our best to help people out where we can.
Equipment decisions can be difficult at the best of times and finding the right equipment can often take a lot of trial and error especially if you can't find any help!
Short explanation in a different thread.
Those are my thoughts on difference between hard and soft rubber.
I have no scientific foundation to prove that it works that way, but it makes sense to me...
I found your reply very very interesting.
So, if i understood, in your opinion, a soft.
rubber need less strenght(should, arm and forearm) and more rotation with legs and body.
Isn't it?If it is true, best player chose hard rubber because they can shot with less time than soft rubber, they have more speed because use strenght and degrees give power, but they lack of spin.
Isn't it?
Is that opposite of what people generally use?
Usually the soft rubber is in the BH with short stroke.

I used to use a T05 for the BH (shorter stroke) and now in trying to develop a backhand loop (longer stroke) I'm using the T05FX.Problem I found with the softer rubbers on the FH is that the arc flattens out on a stronger hit so I use a medium rubber.Have noticed the odd player using a harder rubber on the BH than the FH but that is more the exception.Using a hard rubber can work on a softer blade e.g.
a Nittaku Violin with something like an Evolution MX-P on the FH but if one was using a composite blade most would prefer a medium rubber.
IMHO a MX-P would be too hard on the BH unless you were a pro.
If you were looking to develop a backhand loop a medium soft rubber would be more suitable.

I'm sorry to go against other opinions in the thread, but from what i know and experimented, usually:Spin: H > SSpeed: H > SArc: H > SThrow angle: H > s(The belief that softer rubbers result in more spin IMHO belongs to the old time of speed glueing, when the rubber was spinnier if it was softer.

With modern tension rubber it's not like that anymore... it's the opposite, so for example Tgy, bluefire, evolution, vega and sigma and all other rubbers have more spin potential in their hard version than in their soft)The true advantage in using a softer rubber is the "control", because a softer rubber usually1) Is less sensitive to spin, so it's better to block easy (lower throw)2) Is slower3) Has more dweell time4) MOST IMPORTANT: a softer rubber works well even with a soft stroke, whereas a harder rubber usually needs a harder stroke to work well, so essentially hard rubbers have more potential but are harder to use and they are created to play at a higher level.

Softer rubbers engage the ball more easily and so enable the player to play lighter shots and control the ball easily.This also sometimes helps to spread the false belief that soft rubbers = more spin, because if your loop is not quite strong you will indeed create more spin with a softer rubber, but if your loop has good quality your potential with a harder rubber is higher!!
!In fact in world's top 100 you will see that almost everybody uses hard rubbers, expecially on their fh where thay want more arc and power.

Someone uses softer rubber on the bh to improve the block and the touch, usually players who doesn't search for maximum power on their bh...And at last, if you have a strong swing and use a rubber which is too soft, it might "bottom out".

That means that the ball enters in the rubber too much and engages the blade, resulting usually in a strange and missed hit...If you write what your playstile is, your actual paddle and how you like to play your forehand and backhand we can help you in your choice too!

I agree with what RevannII said.One more factor IMHO is harder sponge has better precision/accuracy.
Skilled players with very high racket speed may not want overly long dwell which causes too much carry and a delay in the ball release.
For them soft sponge is like a slow delayed reaction trampoline effect even if they can keep from bottoming it out.
Ok today i tried a Jp01 on forehand and a Jp03 on a Innerforce ALC.Very happy about Jp01 on forehand, very good control, enough spin(it was a bit better baracuda), very good speed, ok on blocking.
It is a medium hard rubber, i think it is a starting point to will go on hard rubber in future.
very good on looping near table, good far away on table if used strenght, very good on counterloops.

M1 turbo and Jp01 turbo are much better but in my opinion it would be a too high jump if switched from baracuda.Not so happy about Jp03 on backhand, a bit slow, baracuda was better on catapult and spin but very very good control and best choice for counterloops.Next week i will try a M2 on backhand, before i want try these two rubbers a couple of days.

I'm happy to see you are getting close to your aim  My advice is to avoid rubbers wich are too extreme, because even if they have better potential they are quite more difficult to use and require more skill and spin understanding... every time i canged from a most powerfull/spinnier/most difficult setup to a less powerfull/less spinny/less difficult setup it improved my game a lot, an not only because i'm a defender  I mean my attacking skills also!
Above all i found the problem isn't usually if the rubber is too fast, but if it's too spin sensitive.

They are beautifull because they are able to do powerfull shots and cuts with minimum effort, but they could damage your progress as a player  I think your setup is good enough to play in any league, maybe if you have a strong backhand tospin you migh consider a harder rubber even there, but that said, i think you could be happy with your racket untile at least 3rd category  Cheers

I've used them both and liked both..They are of 2 different beast.. will depend on your taste and style.
In my case both rubbers worked on either of my fh and bh,which is excellent.
I can switch to 2 different setups in a match, an excellent advantage.

Though I only switch when I see amarginal weakness within a certain shots to prevent an opponent from capitalizing on it and finding a better counter for it at the same time.if both will work on you but tried one of them first and the other later, you might not like the later rubber..whichever of the 2 you would have tried first.
in my case, I've played with Rasant first and liked it so much..then I tried Rhyzm and hate it initially.
After a while, a put the Rhyzm back and gave it more time,gradually I began to like it as much as Iiked Rasant.
So, I put them both together but remember, this time I am more used to Rhyzmand just playing again on Rasant with it, at this time I didn't like the Rasant..

Which ist a turn around.Upon experimenting from it, switching rubbers from bh to fh and vice versa by turning the blade.. as I get used to both,I've now began to like both on both sides, each rubber having different advantage levels on either side.
Being 2 different rubbers,I can make use of the goods of the other rubber over the weakness of the other in my shots.

An excellent combo I must say.. at least for me.For the part of how the two compare and differ,I'll just rate them here against each one.Speed ------ Rasant is faster and stifferSpin ------- Rhyzm is spinier and more forgivingControl ---- Overall both rubbers are Equals, the control level varies on each strokes.Blocking --- Rhyzm better on passive, Rasant better on active.Short game-- Overall both rubbers equally excel, depending on which side of the hand you use them for.Flicks ------ Rhym better control on bh but equals Rasant on fh.
Likewise, Rasant has better direction on fh.Neutrals/Negatives Rasant is faster and not spin sensitive against incoming spins, but less spiny.
Rhyzm is spinnier and more controllable, but more sensitive to incoming spins.

Rasant is heavy on large blades but ads firmness to a lighter rubber on the other side of blade Rhyzm is light but adds no attribute effect to the other rubber.Blade used is 20 year old Armstrong Level 91.Much faster than Mizutani and less stiffer.. a tad faster than Viscaria.Hope these helps.. °Q(ツ)/

I'm going to chip in!Genius is old generation.
It's not particularly bad, but the newer tensors are much better in terms of durability and short game control.
I still like Genius Sound on the BH side, but Aurus Sound or Soft was a definite improvement on that.5Q is excellent.
A really good FH rubber - it's a great choice.
You'll love it on the Maze.5Q Sound is a very interesting rubber.
It's a lot softer than other recent "soft" tensors like Rasant Powersponge or Bluefire JP-03.
It also has quite a soft topsheet.
It's a spin monster.
It's very nice over the table - excellent short control, if a little jumpy.
But it's very high throw on harder shots.
I don't like this on my BH - I need medium throw or below.I use 1Q Sound on the FH, and it makes a good BH rubber too.
It is faster than 5Q Sound, medium throw, powerful, good spin, and so suits me more than 5Q Sound, but it's a personal thing.If you want a high-throw, soft BH rubber, 5Q Sound is excellent.
It compares really well to Tenergy 05-FX, for example.
If you don't like high throw, consider 1Q Sound (or one of the other 1000's of options).

The MM that the guy in the video is using a Flared handle.

I have used the Innova UL with 1,5-1,8 sponge on Re-Impact balsa blades (my own and my son's).

My impression is that it bottoms out easily, but that compared to most rubbers there is a more gradual transition from spinny (when engaging sponge) to a spin-insensitive flat-hit rubber (when the sponge is more or less "bypassed" through bottom-out).
Not sure whether that effect is due to rubber topsheet, sponge, balancing firmness in topsheet and sponge, an effect of balsa, or my imagination.

The boy is still using it, and it gives sufficient spin and speed for his abilities, with the added control you mentioned.For myself I found that I needed more headroom for speed and spin, so I changed from the Innova to the KTL pro XP.
For my game, they are not so different.
The KTL only a little more "reactive", which works both ways, of course (it is also more sensitive to incoming spin).
keme: many txs your reply.
I had noticed that you used Innova at one time and the reason for your shift to KTL is clear.
Will continue to use the Innova and perhaps the weaknesses--other than the slower speed I mentioned--will develop.
But at this point, am really quite satisfied.
My side spin short loops from about 1m were great tonight causing difficulty for blockers and Seemiller types.
Still......am always skeptical about something that seems so good.
Will keep informing.

I play a modern defensive game with long pips on the backhand.

thread_title: Comparing Tenergy 05/64 vs Rasant vs Bluefire M1/M2/M3

Bluefire is heavier, has higher topsheet grip, bigger feeling of "dwell", a touch slower, higher throw, better for looping, worse for hitting and blocking, sponge is smellier and more porous.I'm mainly comparing S3 and M3 here, but I've used S1-3 and M1-3 and I think it holds true for all the sponge hardness versions.
I haven't used S1 Turbo tho.
Try Flextra 1.7
For classical defense?
I was specifically going with Tackiness Chop because it's so dang slow (which is of particular importance since the Joo Se Hyuk isn't a super slow blade).
I currently use Tackiness Drive (on a different blade), and it's comparable in speed to Flextra according to tabletennisdb.
That's faster than what I'm hoping for.
Don't rely on TableTennisDB for everything.
People have different opinions on rubbers, and your findings will be different from a lot of people.
I think its better to have a non-tacky rubber for forehand chopping, but thats just me.

I'm not a forehand chopper, also I'm a beginner, so that makes my opinion a little biased towards my stylel and playing capabilities.Also its cheaper than Tackiness Chop by about 10 US dollars.Keep in mind there are a ton of Chinese tacky rubbbers that play similarly (slow, controllable) to Tackiness Chop for half the price.Cream MRS 1.5 being one of them.
Unfortunately, my chopping and looping strokes don't work well with Chinese/tacky rubbers.
While I haven't played with it myself, I know Tackiness Chop is more non-tacky/grippy, despite its name.
The same is true of Tackiness Drive, which is similar, but a bit more elastic, with a slightly more lively sponge.

That last part is kind of the problem with my current setup, with regard to forehand chopping, though, and is what I worry would be the same with Flextra; more "dead" feeling sponges make forehand chopping far easier, even though it is possible to chop with any rubber.

hey matei use acuda s2 on tb alc blade on both sides and are great,have not tried rakza 7s1 imo is to hard of sponge and a bit fast for me and the s3 is to slow and sponge is to softs2 has great feel,speed,spin,control and wont let you downhope this helps
I used Rakza 7 on my previous blade.
It's fast, firm, with a high enough throw that makes looping backspin easy.
Blocks pretty well, and counterloops really well.
I don't really dislike anything about this rubber, but I've never played with acuda s2.
I've tried acuda s3 and found it to be a good soft backhand rubber much like a slightly firmer yet more spinney f3.
Actually I haven't tried rakza 7 on my new blade...maybe I should.
Which is spinnier: Acuda S2 or R7?
Which has more dwell time?
I'm assuming R7's slightly faster?
I have tried both.
If you are just at beginner/intermediate level, I'd recommend using the Acuda S2.The S2 is more forgiving than the Rakza 7.
The one problem from my experience with Rakza 7 is in service returns.
It has a tendency to bring the ball high which makes you prone to flick drives/smash.
It's also a bit tricky when trying to use it for chopping.On the blades that I have used, I find the Acuda S2 has better dwell time than the Rakza 7.
The Acuda S2 for me, among the Donic rubbers, is the all-around rubber.
That's my standard FH rubber I use when I want to test a new blade and from there, decide which rubber would I use on my blades.
I have a spare S2 sheet for blade testing.
when I was using rakza 7, my loops were giving people a few hundred points better than me trouble since I could load them up with spin with plenty of speed.
Acuda s2 is faster less spinny last time a played it.
Razka 7 all the way there is no real comparison to S2 R7 is a lot more spiny and thats what you want for an all-round attaker.If you want to be smart, put R7 on forehand and S2 on backhand.

No problem - it's tricky talking about rubber sometimes when you don't know where the other person is at (hence my use of question marks).
You are correct that tensors are generally bouncier than the old staples but I think it is just something you learn to adjust to after a short while.
From memory Roxon is somewhere in between Mark V and Rasant/T05.
It's a good do-anything rubber.
T05/Rasant are better suited if you are an advanced looper/counter-looper.
This is IMO of course.Edit - Whilst it id not identical with Rasant/T05 I would throw Calibra into the same advanced looping category.
Sorry, was away for a day and couldn't answer.
My way of describing Rasant would be a similar speed to Roxon 450 with greater spin and better control.
I played with R450 for about 2 years, then went to Hexer Plus basically.
H+ was an ounce slower than R450 with less "bounce" so its control was better, and similar spin.
Rasant has re-instated the speed of my FH back to R450, still with less "bounce" but with greater spin capabilities.
I think its awesome, and in keeping with an "Andro" feel.
I would totally agree (re Calibra).
Never played with it, but someone I played last week used it on their FH and the speed of their loops compared to what they previously used (don't recall what that was) was highly pronounced.

The way you describe it, it sounds as if it's just what i' m looking for then.Better spin, better control, but as fast as 450.My spinny serves are an essential part of my game, and if I can generate more spin, it sounds like a very good alternative.
I tried pryde some time ago, but found it very hard to generate spin on the serves.
But it is a lot harder isn't it?With roxon 450 i've had max on fh and one step slower on bh, so that would probably be a good idea on rasant as well?
It would IMO.
A word of advice though, I'd change one rubber at a time.
Rasant is harder to get the spin out of from soft contact.
It took me a little while to adjust and get as much spin on serves, but I feel I have after a few rounds with it.
Thats coming from Hexer+ though.
If I came straight from the bouncier R450, it might not be as hard to adjust.
Still, I would expect an adjustment period of some degree.
So it is a bit harder than roxon 450 then?
Probably is, I couldn't say for sure, simply because I wouldn't think there'd be 5 degrees in it...which means I'd need a gauge to tell properly.
Thanks for your help.
I think I"ll buy rasant, unless somebody has something very favourable to say about calibra.
I know there is a lot of good to be said about Calibra, but I can only say from an opponents point of view.
That's one step removed from being able to say anything directly about it really.
Kinda like "hearsay"
I finally decided on calibra sound and played with it for the first time yesterday.
Wow, it fler Greta.Roughly the same speed as roxon 450, but control was a lot better.
Spin does not leave much to be desired either.I have always liked roxon 450, but also felt that I lost some unneccesary balls when chopping.Nille
Good to hear you found that you liked it Nille.
I'd love to see you find some Rasant to use now to compare it.
Yes, I'd really like to compare the two.
I have used Calibra Sound and really liked it for counter-looping and looping block.
When you first use it it has a great glue effect on those shots.
I seem to recall that this effect eventually waned but I'm not sure at what stage.
The main problem I had with Calibra Sound was the relative lack of spin.
It's more difficult to get heavy topspin and as a result one gets less dip and the plane of the loop is flatter.I have played with Rasant for 10 minutes or so.
IMO it is a different type of rubber than Calibra Sound.
The sponge is harder (not super hard but harder than Calibra Sound) and I think (I'm not 100% sure) the top sheet is thicker.
Rasant has better spin than Calibra Sound.

I hope the glue effect Will last for quite some time, sinceStiga's rubbers are usually good quality.My impression-i've only played with it once- is that I was able to generate a lot of spin on loops close to the table as well as on loops further away.
Above all, the control was impressive although it is a fast rubber.
Our experiences differ but the main thing is that you are happy with it.
Yes the Calibra sound has quite a lot softer sponge.
The glue effect is very high, I think mainly because with soft sponges the glue tends to feel much stronger.

My practice partner use the Calibra sound... he can get very high spin but only at medium pace.. since he tend to either play medium pace loops and smashes when he wants to put it away, it works very well for him.

I think both rubbers would be good for you, although the sponges on them could be a little soft when playing hard attacking shots even in 2.0 or 2.2mm.

The submarine would certainly suit the style your describe... the 1.5mm a bit more control for chopping, the 1.8mm a bit more offensive potential.

Very good spin and controland insensitive to spin.
http://www.ttdd.de.deIf you don't chop much 1.8 or 2.0mm will suit your game.I haven't tried submarine but it certainly soundslike good pick as well.
cheersGeddk
Hi,Some of my clubmates use submarine and one uses marder.
Submarine is somewhat more solid feeling and has more power reserve while passive it,s slower off it can be more dangerous.
Marder is more fragile, lighter, with thinner base for the topsheet.
Both are nice but on harder off blades I found submarine can be more effective for a miscellaneous game.

Marder I only played one trainingsmatch for testing tough so impression is brief.For submarine I guess 1,5 for allround, 1,0 more defence tendency and 1,8/2,0 for more offensive tendency but 2,0 more for fh or longer bh stroke ; For me not quick enough for bh not spinny on chops and pushes either.
I played 1,8 myself for a few months on bh.
1,0 several sessions and trainingsmatches (same type of game with off blade).
1,5 version only short tested on other players bat was a good medium, most allround for me.
If I - possibly -buy it again for myself it,s going to be 1,5.More serious chopping 1,0 is better but I would use a bit softer blade then.
Galaxy w-6 or something in that range or also all round and defensive blades.
You can chop with it as if digging a hole in the floor then (for maximum spin) or chopblock close at the table.
Specifically a black 1,0 version worked well for this.1,8 is better for bh opener with a longer arm and in open play continued loop-attack from mid distance.
It needs to follow through more, too much for me (the allround could be better for that when it has same topsheet with a faster sponge).
Over the table spinny opening brushloops 1,5 is better.
Quicker, better, response to me for wrist.
And attacks from mid distance can use the blade ; Just whack the ball with enough spin to land works well.Due to topsheet all versions play relatively thick.
1,0 feels more like 1,2 or even 1,5.
Topsheet is not typically slow but allows good dwell for "catching" the ball under attack for a spinblock and reverse spin, chop or anything.
Short dropped spinblocks putting the ball where I want had superb control for sharp angles and length.
Also parallel (important for me as a lefty) or as a short stopblock.
Not much spinsensitive for this but decent counterspin gives a sharp enough bounce and second dip.
1,5 I found most balanced thickness for this but other versions worked well also.Some susceptibillity comes in offcourse when pushed further from table nailed at bh side by a strong off player.
Continuous chopping is not real strong and save option then (on an off blade).
Counterattacking not real strong either.

But in 1,5 all these things are possible.But, in general, continuous variation becomes key ; Chopblocks, keeping ball flat and low with some pace, a halfhigh lobspin, as spinny as possible, use of sidespin, corkscrew and whatever comes in mind.More heavy chops on occasion also.
With enough and continuous variation, if possible some deceptive use of wrist, most opponents can be triggered to make "mistakes" or offer chances for fh.
The reason this is succesfull with this rubber (to me, maybe helped by playing lefthand) is that all these strokes can be done a bit more agressive then usual thanks to good control.
Not giving to much time and always some spin that seems to be difficult to read.
It becomes almost a long pips game then except pips are reversed to lp inverted and you have to be active for the deception (as with grippy long pips).
No idea how the allround compares (curious for that as well) but submarine is the only rubber where I could play such a game without feeling too handicapped for a more standard attacking game.

It needs a fh rubber that also allows to stay close to table ; flatter throw, not too fast but hard sponge, tacky rubber is perfect for me to combine with.A so much fun game that I think it deserves this try for a review.
Great review ghrasp!
Thank you all for your responses.
It seems as if no one has been able to try Giant Dragon Allround.
I'm interested to know if it does indeed have the same topsheet as Submarine.
It sounds like Submarine in 1.5mm might be my best option for my backhand if I want the ability to switch seamlessly between offense and defense.

I really appreciate the advice so far, and I welcome any more you can provide.I just received a sheet of Reflectoid 1.5mm to try and I can already tell with a simple bounce test that it is substantially slower than my CJ8000.
I'm excited to see how it chops on my Timo Boll Spirit tomorrow.
If I can't mix in over the table attacks with it I'll have to try something else.
Submarine and Dr. Neubauer Domination 1.5mm are the only two choices that seem to come highly recommended for my style of play.
Who knows, I may decide to be the first Guinea pig for Giant Dragon Allround.
I haven,t tried reflectoid.
It has similar idea from reviews but must be different then submarine because of weight difference.
Reflectoid is extremely light and submarine is medium.

I suspect this will give submarine the edge for shielding off the fast bounce from an off blade with a tangential stroke and keeps the ballcontact a bit longer (to be able to do something in critical situations).
Spinlord marder could be in between (at least weightwise it was according to ttdd.de site when they still sold reflectoid) with lighter topsheet then submarine but heavier sponge then reflectoid.
Reflectoid, as with marder, I expect to play better on somewhat softer wooden blades in off- range for instance the w-6 (also nice headsize for chopping) or modern defensive blades.
The light weight avoids a too headheavy setup then and for fh attack these blades become better (quicker response) to stay at the table.
For less headheavy handling but also the throwangle on fh can be kept flatter under pressure.
More flexy blades behave stiffer and quicker when the setup is less headheavy and can be played more agressive with.
For instance Tenergy and the likes (high throw, heavy) with reflectoid bh will still play well enough for blocks, smashes and counters at the table with keeping same time a good looping abillity.
At both sides these rubbers need faster blades for that
isn't 1.5mm always best for that requirement?
I use therefore cj8000 1.5mm on BH with a slower blade and it fits me perfectly.
Switching SEAMLESSLY is just what I do, increasing spin stroke by stroke (in contrast to Polina  http://www.laola1.tv/en/int/tischtennis ... 0138-.html )
What 1.5mm sponge do you use under CJ8000?
purple sponge 36-38° ("extreme spin")
Is that a Palio pre-made option, or did you get it custom made with that sponge?
it's premade from ttdd.deanyway, I did not want to focus with my posting on cj8000.

my message was:no matter what rubber use, guess it's one out of sriver, coppa, cj8000, submarine, quattro, high super, marder, neos, 007, higher, geospin, ... i'd always prefer 1.5mm for an allround-game with defensive and spinny offensive shots.
I think you are right, it's just a matter of finding the best 1.5mm for my game.
I appreciate the advice.
I tried Reflectoid 1.5mm and it was ok for chopping, but the offensive capabilities were not good enough for my game.
I'll have to keep looking.
There are a view different topsheets for palio cj-8000.

Standard and three versions (A, B and C).Extreme speed, extreme balance and extreme spin use the A,B and C. Don,t ask me which is A and which is C but extreme balance is in the middle so that would be B.
Sometimes also offered as cj-8000 spintype, speedtype aso.
Spintype has longer more supple pips making the topsheet more flexible.
while speedtype has shortest pips.Their is some simillarity with submarine but if extreme spin is C then submarine would be D : "extreme control" with even more supple topsheet.
Submarine is less tacky, red almost none-tacky.
Less linear katapult therefor a wider range of gears.
This range of gears (similar as Hurricane III has) makes it possible to vary between defensive and offensive shots but also has higher risk for being caught in between.
1,5 is certainly the best entry and most allround but 1,0 has more contrast to fh, and additional control allows to be more active with it at the table making it nastier for opponent.
I may misunderstand you here, but are you saying Submarine is less linear than CJ8000?
One of my favorite qualities of CJ8000 is the linear way in which you get what you put into it.
I am not a fan of surprises such as a medium speed swing resulting in an unnaturally fast shot.
Predictability is important to my style since I so often switch between chopping back loops and hitting them as well.
Do you think Submarine has a tendency to lose it's linear quaility when swinging very hard?
I suppose you could mean that it has a wide range of gears, from very slow over the table shots all the way to very fast smashes.
This is a good thing as long as it does not become unpredictable.
Is this what you mean?
That Submarine seems to have a wider range of gears than the CJ8000 variants you have tried?
If you hate Hurricane III maybe don,t buy or try.

Hurricane III is predictable (after a while of use once you know it well) but far from linear as how japanese classic rubbers are linear ; Submarine has a wide range of gears also and it,s very variable from this once you know it well for alternating between attack and defence.
But shifting gears needs some feeling with it.As with hurricane you can easy disconnect to the katapult (it seems to have none then).
Deliberately this is perfect for an alternating game.
But it can also happen accidental at times.
It has more risk for that.
Then it,s maybe not as forgiving as palio.
Maximum spin on pushes against backspin is not as good as with palio.
Probably because the topsheet of palio has more powerfull pipsstructure.
Less air between topsheet and sponge.
This is why palio is heavier also.Counterspin, backspin or topspin this is less powerfull.
A pointscoring attack with submarine needs slamming the ball with a punchblock technicque that contacts the blade well.
A faster blade supports that a lot offcourse.
It only needs little opportunity for this.
Somehow there always seems to be enough spin coming with it for the ball to land.

Have you also read this thread in its entirety?
viewtopic.php?f=44&t=17024HD is a tensor.
The difference between 1st generation through to later generations is basically development of technology and durability in the rubbers.
The earlier tensors were prone to oxidisation of the topsheet and also cracking/crumbling at the edges badly.
Old tensors came with a sticky protector sheet to help prevent the oxidisation, whereas newer tensor don't now because they have solved the problem.
Later tensors have tended to have more speed or spin built into them too.
Yeah i have read it but there is no comparison between those rubbers at least I didnt see it
The Jupiter is both harder and faster, so you should use the faster rubber on your more attacking side.
I deffinitely prefer harder rubbers to go on my forehand side.
On the backhand side, I want to be able to spin the ball with more ease.
This is difficult with harder rubbers.Just make sure you do reviews of the rubbers so everyone gets your impressions on them.
Today I received my new Jupiter fresh from Haggisv and with great eagerness I put it on.
My skill at putting on the rubbers must be getting better as it wasn't nearly has hacked as last time and was nearly a nice oval type shape.

Complete with edge tape its come up pretty micky schmick.My set-up is as follows: -Blade: Sunflex Hurrican (sic*), no idea how its rates as its an old premade for about $25.FH: Red Jupiter 2.2mm 38degree 43 hardness (whats the difference anyway??

)BH Black Mercury 2.2mm 36 degree unsure of hardness but assuming around the 40 mark.Beware if looking for some meaningful information from this post as I have little experience in rubbers so really haven't much to compare to.The first thing I noticed was that the rubbers both seemed really jumpy compared to my current 729 Super FX Lightening.

I did hit a few long but this was soon fixed by hitting with a more closed blade and hitting through the ball more.The feel was a bit more dead than what I am used to (perhaps contradicting the above) where I can often feel the contact with the blade but with these rubbers it was only on the real power shot that I could feel and hear the blade.
Maybe this is the extra thickness of the rubbers I'm not sure.

It didn't bother me but was a bit different.The speed off the bat didn't seem to be any faster however the Jupiter advertises that it zings off the table and it certainly did seem to do this with a noticable kick.I'm trying to develop my technique for looping and found that these rubbers actually helped me do that, perhaps if I didn't, the control wasn't there or perhaps the spin wouldn't be generated to keep the ball on the table.The one thing I can't really tell is if these differences are the blade, the rubbers or both.Since tonight was just a friendly hit, I didn't do any spinny serves to see if they seem to generate more or less spin on the serve.I'm considering using the new set up on the next comp night but not sure yet, might have another practice first, after all whats the point of being an apprentice EJ and have a custom bat and not use it.

Later on, if you want more punch in your strokes when I would recommend 729 bomb to you.Very cheap and versatile blade  You have to be very careful when you take mercury 2 off your blade.Sponge is very fragile.I bought 4 pieces and I have regret itLkt rubbers, like xp, xt is much better for your bh in my opinion.CheersGeddk
that crumbly sponge that seems to snap is quite common with Yin-he rubbers
I've now taken my set-up to the club a few times and its sparked a bit of interest.
A few A grade players who are a lot better than me had a go and actually have all commented that the Mercury II (black) is faster than the Jupiter (red).

In fact, they felt very fast and combined with a fast blade would be 'dynamite'.Apart from playing, one just tapped the ball up in the air several times and the extra height off the blade was visibly noticable for the Mercury II.Its very interesting as I've been using the Mercury on BH and Jupiter on FH since I thought the Jupiter was faster.
Didn't really trial the other way as I just took it for granted but now perhaps I'm going to have to go the other way.
There lies the problem to define which rubber is faster...The Jupiter has a much harder sponge, whereas the mercury II has a soft springier sponge.

On low impact the mercury II will feel more lively and can generate pace with less effort, but when you start looping hard, the sponge will bottom out and your speed comes from the blade not the rubber.
The Jupiter sponge is firm enough not to bottom out, and at high impact will still generate good speed and spin even on a slower blade.

in other words, for the Mercury II the power of the blade will come into it much earlier than that for Jupiter, and the Jupiter can generate good pace without the aid of the blade, whereas the mercury II will run out of puff, and at high impact you'll get the speed from the blade not the rubber, which usually means you won't get much spin either as the sponge 'bottoms' out.So which is the faster rubber?
it all depends on your definition of speed and how you use the rubber...
Interesting comments haggisv.
Perhaps like beauty, speed is also in the hands of the beholder.
Maybe rather than just doing little bounces on the bat of say 15cm or so, perhaps another test should be done where we try hit the roof of the building.

Using this extra force and higher bat speed, perhaps the blade would have more impact and the Jupiter produce more speed and therefore more height.If the blade were a DEF blade, could this bring the test back in more of the Mercury II again ?
Lately after I put on new rubbers I like to stretch the remnants to see how much tension is required to snap the rubber/sponge.
I have noticed that MercuryII/MarsII break remarkable easy (I think I also did this with Moon but I can't remember).
Whereas 2008xp and PalioCJ8000/Quattro take much more force....
I'm talking a very big difference.

The Yinhe rubbers snap almost immediately, the others mentioned have to be stretched so much you'll probably get some sharp backlash on your fingers.I haven't used the MercII or MarsII long enough to know if this physical property correlates to durability; but I find it interesting.
Also, I rarely hit my paddle against the table so I don't have any feedback in that regard.

The main difference between the two is that H3 has a higher throw, making it a little easier to loop with, whereas the H2 tend to be a little easier to block or counterloop.
Both have quite a 'dead' feel and are tacky, which is quite different from Euro-type rubbers.
Perhaps you could consider the Hurricane Neo series, which are softer and more lively, which is quite a step closer to harder sponged Euro type rubbers.
If you are really looking for a Chinese rubber that is closer to the style of euro rubbers you should really look into Dawei Inspirit, or Saviga.
They are much much closer than any of the DHS stuff, other than possibly Tin Arc WHICH WE ARE STILL WAITING FOR A REVIEW OF!

I've used Rakza 7 for the last 5 months.
I use red, max on my forehand.
I really really like this rubber.
I like to topspin attack over or just behind the table on my forehand side.
I find it gives plenty of spin (dips late and hard), control and enough speed and it's lasted well.
For me it doesn't have the springy feel of a lot of typical euro rubbers and so I find I have better control with it and I like the feel of the sponge (hardness wise).
I can definitely hit and smash and topspin with it and I find it good for blocking too.
It's not overly reactive to spin but again technique will help you cope with incoming spin as much as the rubber.

I can use the rakza away from the table looping but for me it's better nearer the table where I find it really excels.However, I lent my bat to a friend who uses tenergy 05 forehand and backhand and has done for a long time.
He felt the Rakza was ok, nothing special, certainly not as much spin for him and he preferred his tenergy (tenergy to me feels quite mushy in comparison to the Rakza).

Somebody else who has borrowed my bat and also uses tenergy 05 / 64 thought the Rakza was more springy than the Tenergy he used but after a few minutes trying it out he quite liked it - but not as much as his tenergy.Never used hexer, sorry.
You might want to also consider the new Palio Blitz Soft (42*).
Very spinny and fast yet surprisingly resistant to incoming spin.. an effortless blocking rubber.
I would have similar comments to Debater about Hexer Plus.
I haven't used normal Hexer and I haven't used Razka 7.
My teammate has T05 on his FH and Hexer powersponge on his BH.
He has that setup for similar reasons to what you are seeking.
Thanks for answers.I'm in dilema, again RebornTTEvnglist can you tell me more about Hexer PS, and is your teammate happy with it?
Also, can somebody give me a site where i can buy Blitz, i heard it is cheap so i'll give it a try.
Rakza soft is faster than Hexer, a better one for attacking.
Hexer is a little more grippy, good at blocking, serving and short play.
Rakza is not bad at this though.
Hexer has a higher throw, more difficult to attack from mid distance.
Both are very good rubber, I think Hexer last longer.
Rakza got a little tired after a month or two.
My Hexer worked nice on a Stiga NCT Allround but not on my JoomSe Hyuk.
You could also consider Xiom Vega Europe or Omega IV Europe, little softer and more control, and higher throw than Rakza.
Xiom's harder rubbers (pro-version) could be what you need.
Both my teammate and I have used Hexer PS.
He has a different style to me, he's more of a brush looper.
I found it to be a good medium throw rubber (normal Hexer is higher throw as def-attack said), but not as fast as the other Hexers, but only marginally.
Enough that opponents noticed my smashes were just a little more possible to return than Roxon 450 though.

The advantage Hexers have over Roxon is they are not as bouncy though, so FH push and chop is easier to control.My teammate had HPS on both sides for quite a long time and his game developed nicely with that.
Very spinny and well fast enough.
He switched his FH rubber to T05 and got even more spin, but kept with HPS on BH still and when he is hitting confidently the shots he rips from his BH are out of sight!
He is most certainly happy with it.
He actually went to it from normal Hexer.My switch from HPS to H+ gave me back a little more speed (still not quite Roxon level) and maintained the control properties of Hexer.
It also suits my style with a low throw.
I wonder how Rakza compares on speed with Roxon 450?
I have used both Hexer and Hexer+.
They are quite different.
Throw is much lower on H+ and it is softer and faster.
But the topsheet on hexer is more grippy.
i never liked H+, never figured out how to loop with it (used it for about 2-3 sessions).
And I really liked the grip of Hexer .
I went to T64 1,9 mm from Hexer 2,1 mm and got more speed and a lot more control, especially when counterlooping, looping and fishing from distance.
My first sessions with T64, it felt like I could not miss anything, whatever I did, the ball landed on the table .
Chopping was MUCH easier than with Hexer.
Too bad it is soooo expensive  .
But I got almost the same feeling with Xiom Omega IV Europe (2,3 mm), very good control and spin and enough speed for counters and looping from distance.
I am currently using H2 Neo and also TG3 Neo.H2 Neo is firm, fast, and spinny.
Its throw is low.
Great for close to the table play.
Control is excellent.
Blocking is excellent.
Starts tacky but mostly wears off after 5-6 matches.
H2 Neo is my main rubber at this time; my previous rubber being Tenergy 25.TG3 Neo is firmer, faster, and spinnier.
Higher throw than H2 Neo.
More spin on serves and loops.
Less control overall, and seems to work better on slower, flexier blades.These were both purchased from FastPaddle.com and came in packaging that indicates hardness.
They are not provincial or national variants.

In a nut shell, H2 is the biggest gun in the DHS gun rack ie for the most offensive players, TG3 is the best overall and great on blades like P500, Primorac -off of anything with a bit of bend in it,TG2 is similar.
H3 is a more dynamic and much less stable version of H2, it doesn't seem to really have anything special going for it that can't be done better with TG3
What CHinese rubbers have you tried Skippy?
None of them are going to feel as lively as your XIOM or Andro rubbers, but they are some very good CHinese rubbers around.
H3: allround rubber.
Can do anything, but nothing greatH2: battleship.
Most demanding rubber, but gives back the most if you can get it out.
To hot to handle for meTG3: medium between H2 and H3.
Very fast, and very good for topspins, bot close and medium range.
Nowhere near as demanding as H2.
My choice

Well, I have played very well with the Hexer+ on my forehand, and Vega Euro on my backhand, but here lately I have been playing with Hexer+ on backhand and Globe 999 Natty on my forehand cause I liked how soft the Hexer+ felt on my backhand while at the same time having nice performance.
I put the Natty on my forehand to "slow down" my forehand and control the table a bit more.
I don't much care for H2 cause the throw is just too low for my liking.

I liked my H3 Neo and had the most significant win of my life playing with H3, but when I hear people describe the Skyline 2 as like H3 with a slightly softer topsheet that makes me think it would be a nice performer for me.
My drawback from the Hexer+ on my forehand isn't so much that I can't hit a slow loop but that it just seems a much more difficult shot to pull the trigger on, and the shot is more difficult.
The 999 Natty probably slows down my forehand a little more than I want it slowed down however the slow loop is so easy a monkey could do it even without opposable thumbs.
The Hexer+ speeds it up a little more than I would like.

Would the 999 Turbo, or Skyline II be a better choice as an in between of these two?Oh, by the way Haggis, I've played All varients of Globe 999 and t, 729 SP, Higher III, Geo Tacky, Cream, Dawei Inspirit, Saviga (inverted), H2, H3, Venus, Venus II, Six Shooter......
I probably liked the SP, Globe Nat, and H3 the most out of the Chinese rubbers I have tried.
Hmmmm?
Compared to the Hurricanes, the 999 topsheets are softer and more elastic, making them a little slower but more spinny especially at lower impact.
The 999 Nat is quite slow and dead at low impact, but when the hard sponge kicks in at higher impact, it's quite fast.
The JUIC 999 CHN and JUIC 999 Turbo are fast at lower gears, but not quite as fast at the highest gear, although they are spinnier for faster loops.
The 999 Turbo is about 15% faster than the 999 CHN, which is probably 20% faster than the regular Globe 999.
I'd suggest you look at the old non-red sponge version of whale.
It's far closer to a glued up 999 national than any of the neo hurricanes/skylines.Incidentally, I hated skyline.
Ridiculously slow.
Those were the regular versions though.
I tried the BWII and actually really liked it quite a bit, but the tuning barely lasted 2 weeks on the sheet I got.
The Chinese need to figure this out so that the performance doesn't change so drastically when the tuning goes away.
Heck if the tuning would last 3-4 months the sheets are well worth it.
If it's only 2 weeks I dunno if it's worth it to me especially since from batch to batch Chinese product varies so much.
How good is the quality control for Haifu?
I have the bluesponge Skyline, and it's very good.
At least 15-20% faster than Globe 999 nat.
Barely slower than h2.

Globe, H3 and TG2 are more suitable for your controlled brush looper, they aren't really stable enough for a power looper, TG3 and H2 are much better there, more stable and more spin when you are full tilt, Globe might give you more on the low end but runs out of spin at 80% arm power, H2 will go all the way with you, TG3 goes somewhere in the middle.
H2 doesn't make much spin on slow shots but it makes the most spin of any Chinese rubber at the very limits, TG3 is nearly a middle man.
You can compare them to you are blue in the face and I have, but in the end the do everything man, TG3 is always the best most of the time
I agree.
At high speeds H2 is a monster, but it's hard to get it there.
And it's a difficult beast to handle at slow speeds.
TG3 is so much easier to play with and you still get very good results with it.
It has a lot of spin, and you can drive all day.
I really couldn't do that with the Globe 999 National.
Where is this bluesponge Skyline sold?
Is it considered Neo?
It's not neo and it's sold by Eacheng and some other companies
Yes its commonly sold in China and HK, It's 38/39 degree not the softer version that you can get in a packet

I'm currently kicking around about 3 or 4 rubbers as a possible forehand rubber.

I want fairly high throw (hopefully consistent throw), pretty long dwell, great spin, decent speed, preferrably a tad softer than Hurricane so that if I have to hit passibly I can still manipulate the ball pretty well without heavy engagement on the ball.
It seems like the harder chinese rubbers have to be actively striking the ball to get the spin and speed.
The other rubbers I'm looking at are Tin Arc, 999 Turbo, Thor's, Skyline II Neo, H3 of some sort.
i think skyline 2 neo would suit you.. i found it very easy to generate spin ( used on clipper wood) and the speed was there as well.as for the top sheet being softer i cant remember all too well.
but i think it was around the same if not harder

I could say both topsheet are firmer with more elastic than Hur.

mm yeah after I had the "this is crap" reaction about outlaw hen everyone else was raving about it, I figured that it was due to the humidity.

Outlaw was the worst I've come accross too, but luckily in our climate, high humidity does not occur often.999 seems to perform well under all condition.... never had a issue.Pimple do not seem affected at all
sort of like a treaded tyre?
mmm Now that would be interesting.

Different versions with the tread running up/down and left/right?

Directional for looping?
I'm in the habit of cleaning rubbers with water then running them across the nearest smooth edge, door frame, towel hanger etc.

Even most tacky rubbers slip beautifully across edges when wet and squeegee themselves dry, Thors wont and it's really annoying for me because that makes it hard to get the water off it quickly, it just shudders across the surface gripping onto it.

As you would expect from having such an annoying tendency the side effect is that it's better than most in humidity but still losses quite a lot of spin when wet, it's playable but still takes the sting out of your shots.
Lucky I don't have to deal with this problem since it's almost never humid here.
Only sometimes when practicing over the Summer break.I don't often use non tacky rubbers but the rapid speed/soft/sound etc topsheets were really unplayable in those conditions
Less tacky rubber which depends on mechenical spin (Eruopean Type) which has more dwell time, potentially should be less affected by moisture.
But, tacky topsheet and comperatively hard sponge rubbers should be more affected with moisture/dust.
T50 topshet feels less tacky if you test with your fingure on the topsheet of T50, but it grips the ball very well because of it's softness/ long dwell time.
So, potentially it should less affected with moisture, dust and swet on it.
I am with Silver.
Xiom Omega II is crap in humidity and gives me an edge in summer when I face opponents using it.
Problem is, when I use Outlaw in summer, it is 10x crappier.
So, Haggisv has it right when he says 999 topsheet is king of conquering the humidity.
My 999 on Quattro is a standyby in summer and never lets me down.
tackier rubbers seem more waterproof on the topsheet, im comparing H2 and H3, 729, sriver FX and cream.
maybe this is connected to outlaws worthless performance in humid weather.

I have tried them both, but a long time apart and on different blades.
Sterco sponge is quite soft and a lot less springy compared to the T64.
I would guess they are similar speed.
Throw of Sterco may be a little lower, but it's not really low.
Sterco is a lot less sensitive to spin, but not quite as spinny, although the spin on Sterco is good and the topsheet very grippy.
Sterco has little glue feel, much less than T64.
I have tried both Sterco and T64.
To me, both rubbers are basically same speed which surprises me quite a bit as I expect the T64 to be that much more faster.
The Sterco is not exactly soft either.
Well, not as soft as I would expect it to be as it is only slightly softer than the T64.
Spin, the Sterco is not as spinny as the T64.
Control wise, I believe the Sterco is better.
Yep, Sterco certainly don't have the glue feel to it.
In fact, it feels a bit dead which is why it surprises me with the speed.
It can pack a punch too with my driving smash.
All in all, a good rubber and quite durable as well.
For its price compared to that of T64, I say it is better value if spin is NOT an important part of your game.
In fact, for lower level player, I would recommend the Sterco over the T64 for its better control.Cheers.
Just received a package of Sterco, quite excited to pit Sterco against T64, since T64 is very expensive.
I don't expect any glue effect on Sterco (unlike T64), but as long as it's easy to play with, that's fine by me.Will do a comparison in a few sessions' time.

), but the gears and feel are quite different.
It doesn't do the 'suck the ball in and spit it out' kind of feel of glued/heavily tuned rubbers.More to come after I tune the bejesus out of this sheet.
