so perhaps I just rephrase.
Can someone compare boost tc with hexer/baracuda?
TC is softer, better glue feel, less grip, less spin on slow strokes (serve/push/brush loop).
Maybe similiar or a bit slower speedwise.
Hexer and Baracuda are Tenergy wannabes.
So the Boost rubbers are easier to play with than Hexer?
Perhaps I should go indeed with TC on FH and TP on BH, although I understand that TP has a very low throw, and I'm not sure if I would like that.
I use a Stiga Boost TX on my backhand and Tenergy 64 on my forehand.
I am VERY happy with the boost TX.
It feels firmer than the Tenergy 64.
It is almost as fast and as spinny as the 64.
It definitely has more control and more gears.
Plays very well with short pushes over the table and flat drives.
It has a softer sponge which allows u to loop well with excellent spin.
The throw angle is a high medium.
For me it is the perfect backhand rubber, no problems with it whatsoever.
To be honest with you, on a scale of 1 to 10, Tenergy 64 is 9, the Boost is 8.5.
I would definitely recomment this rubber but overall tenergy seems better, but not by much.
Thanks, that's useful to know.
I don't have the time (or opportunity) to play more than twice per week, so I think I'll order some sheets of Boost once the current season is finished (only another 4 matches or so).
Humza, your description of TX sounds interesting, I am tempted now to use this one.
Decisions, decisions....
Bear in mind that Hexer and Baracuda are not identical.
Hexer is harder and faster and pretty much better in every way.
Not a whole lot better, but noticeably.
(Obviously this means that some other players might prefer Baracuda.
What this mainly means is they should not be considered exactly the samething).
From what I read I thought that they are virtually identical, with Baracuda only a little bit slower.
Perhaps that would make baracuda also a bit easier to play with?
And how does Tibhar Genius fit in this?
So Hexer is not very forgiving with poorly executed shots.
How is Roxon 450 in that respect?
I'm playing local league level, and very few people are indeed really good at the short game.
Leaning towards Roxon 450 now (but I might change my mind again....).
Very useful advise - many thanks.
In the end I went with baracuda.
Nice rubber, very spinny, durability could be better.
I decided against the boost after reading elsewhere that it is very sensitive to humidity.
I had a hit with Baracuda today, and I really liked it.
I think many people dismissed this rubber as some players reviewed it as being too slow, but I found it plenty fast enough, and it was very spinny.
The sheet I tried certainly wasn't new, but I still got huge kick on my loops, so I suspect durability is not too bad either.

Coming from mainly Chinese rubbers, I've used to having to generate my own pace instead of getting a lot from the rubber, and the speed was quite good, easily faster than many Chinese rubbers, and probably only a little slower than t05.
It's actually quite a bit slower than T05, but one could probably get used to it.
It is quite spinny.

Hi Ilya, I don't know what you think about the 2 rubber sheets.
Do you like Roundell?
How soft is it?
Like a Sriver EL?
How does it compare to Catapult?
Roundell's sponge is similar to Sriver EL, but the topsheet is grippier and faster.
It is easily one of the better allround/offensive rubbers I have seen yet.
Nice thing about Roundell is that is is very elastic, but does not top out.Catapult is, IMO, unadulterated crap.
To be more exact, it is very bouncy at low speed, but tops out at anything beyond 50%.
It is not particularly sensitive to incoming spin, but it is similarly mediocre at creating its own spin.
It is a good rubber for people who primarily block and fish, but it is not particularly good at anything else.ILya
Thanks Ilya.
Did you ever see Brian Pace's review of Catapult on the Butterfly website?
He makes Catapult sound like the best thing since sliced bread.It's nice to have an unbiased review.
No, I have not seen Brian's review.
I have long ago learned to ignore just about all information on the manufacturers' webpages aside from technical details: product name, sponge hardness, number of wood plies, etc.

thread_title: Joola Express 1/2 VS Bryce Speed FX
reply_split: I found the Bryce line of rubber to be excellent in this particular usage.

thread_title: Joola Express 1/2 VS Bryce Speed FX
reply_split: I haven't personally tried the Express 1 or 2, so I can't vouch for them.

thread_title: Joola Express 1/2 VS Bryce Speed FX
reply_split: I used Joola Express 1 last season, and it was the fastest rubber around at the time.

thread_title: Joola Express 1/2 VS Bryce Speed FX
reply_split: Very flat throw, with a low spin level make it the opposite of Tenergy.

thread_title: Joola Express 1/2 VS Bryce Speed FX
reply_split: Great for hitting at the table, excellent for pushing (seems to grip well on slow shots), consistent smashes.

thread_title: Joola Express 1/2 VS Bryce Speed FX
reply_split: The downside is the low spin, which makes it hard work for loopers, but for blockers (you have to be good to control it though) and hitters it's excellent.

thread_title: Joola Express 1/2 VS Bryce Speed FX
reply_split: Pretty hard sponge lacks feel (on an Andro Super Core Off+) but gives a positive air to the rubber - it's getting the ball back rather than sinking in.

thread_title: Joola Express 1/2 VS Bryce Speed FX
reply_split: If you're comparing it to Bryce Speed FX then Express 2 is the similar rubber (softer sponge), which will add some spin and feel at the expense of pace.

thread_title: Joola Express 1/2 VS Bryce Speed FX
reply_split: I'm probably changing to Bryce Speed in the close season (May) unless the new toys they bring out look more fun.Also worth considering Andro Hexer - a loss of speed to the 2 above, but very accurate and quite spinny (can lift pushes easily) and plentry of gears.

thread_title: Joola Express 1/2 VS Bryce Speed FX
reply_split: Plays well attacing over the table with all-out top-spin hits, but durability can be an issue if you play more than 10 hours a week.

t64 isspringiergrabs the ball moreslightly less reactive to spinslightly fastersofter topsheetmuch more durablespinwise YMMV.
I get more spin out of t64 than outlaw.
I will give it a go as it sounds more like the types of rubbers i have been using.
Im used to glued Sriver EL's but want to make the switch to a non glued rubber
adding to what silver said:t-64 more linear than outlaw.t-64 more spin on serves.
Really?
Not my experience, Outlaw is incredibly linear for such a quick rubber.Also add....Outlaw > more money left for beer
only for the first week.
Then you realise you have to replace it every few weeks because it keeps tearing
ha ha!Actually, the new outlaw is vastly improved - not as durable as tenergy I agree, but not bad at all.
I agree on most things but Outlaw is definitely less reactive to spin than Tenergy.
Infact I find Gambler Outlaw to be one of those rubber that's very little affected by the incoming spin.
I have used Outlaw as my main FH weapon of choice the last year on the TBS.
I have now had a week playing T05.
I agree with Sunflex in that Outlaw is WAY faster and also less reactive to spin.
I generate PLENTY of overwhelming power and spin on power loops and medium loops with Outlaw.
Outlaw does not let me down with flat hits either.
Simply a bullet.
Like Silver said, serving with Tenergy is great, but I could get pretty good spin on serves from Outlaw.
T05 sacrifices a ton of speed, but the slow to medium shots simply go in more often and with more spin than it appears.
I did not have this "middle" game very much playing with Outlaw, T05 opens a new world to my game.
T05 isn't T64 of course.
I play against 3 J-Penners who use T64.
T64 to them seems to play like a springier, faster, somewhat (but not much) less spinny version of T05.
Their middle game is awesome, as well as finishing shots.
If I use edge tape to slow down the edge crumbling, and don't tear the sheet on corners or whatnot, I get 6 weeks of daily play 3-4 hours out of Outlaw.
If I am unfortunate and pop a few pips under the topsheet on my power shots, or hit an edge, then into the trash can goes that sheet of Outlaw.
If my sheet of T05 can get 4-5 months out of T05 playing every day a few hours, then it is break even.
As a plus, Tenergy is not nearly affected by humidity like Outlaw is affected.
Good grief, power looping and counter looping with Outlaw in high humidity is a formula to get you highly pissed off.
In light of that, if you can get more than a few months from Tenergy, it is worth it.
The humidity is why I got a sheet of T05.
Late spring and summers here are murder with humidity.
And based on what i have been used to I think T64 will be a closer match for me.
oh ok, haven't tried the new one.i'd say that outlaw is more linear than t64.
Need to put more effort in than t64 for the same speed.
Where could I get this "more durable new line" of gambler ?
How to recognize it ?
Is there a new package ?
Haggisv, do you carry it ?
Unfortunately there wasn't any change to the packaging or external markings.

However, it was a little while ago now and outlaw seems to have been pretty popular so I expect any sheet you bought now would be the new formulation.Don't be under any illusions; it is not a long lasting rubber even now; but it is far better than it was and I no longer break pips despite hitting very hard.

It is the edges that still suffer, but not as much and edge tape seems to help.Unfortunately for Gambler many customers will have given up on the rubber before the improved version was introduced.For humidity issues, I find an occasional 'clean' with spinmax helps tremendously.
I will swap 4 sheets of outlaw for 1 sheet of any tenergy.
(NEW)I know that is a loaded statement and this isnt the equipment buy and sell section - sorry but I think it carries the IMO clause and is a true offer if anyone is interested.
I think for the price i will stick with Outlaw

Silver, I am curious to know why you converted to 1.9mm sponge.

What are (were) the major factors contributing to your decision?I have found that in 2.1, with any kind of positive forward stroke, that many more shots against a slow to medium ball simply go in with control that was never there with other rubbers I tried.
The resulting gain in points, or at least being able to stay in them longer, is a compelling argument to stay with T05 in 2,1 sponge.
I give up the 10X turbo boost finishing power of Outlaw for the ability to hit shots I missed before and trouble the opponent more often.

Trying to control the opening loop.If there's one thing I've noticed with T05 2.1mm is that if you're not constantly practicing or even constantly playing a couple of times a week, it's not a forgiving rubber.
It's difficult to 'back off' successfully and play a safe half-hearted shot.

"On the other hand, it is also easier to create spin with tacky rubbers which might make some people lazy, as it is so easy to create spin with them.
"So would you say you would become a better player with Euro/Jap rubbers because it makes you work harder?
You could use the same argument by saying 'tacky rubbers are more sensitive to spin, so it makes you watch the spin more carefully.

Non-tacky rubbers make you lazy as they are less sensitive to spin'Both styles of rubbers have advantages and disadvantages, so neither is better than the other, they are just different and suit different styles.
This is why you still find both types of rubbers even at the Elite levels.
I think this isn't an issue to argue about.
Some people like a bouncy rubber, others like a linear rubber.
I think people buy the stuff they like, whether Japanese/European or Chinese rubber, because it conforms to what they expect the ball to do when they hit it.
Mostly a matter of ball feeling.I would say that you became a better player as a result of forgetting about the equipment and focusing on the other game elements.
If Euro/Jap makes you play like this, then so be it.
Both have their strengths.

Tacky rubbers are great offensive weapons for the short game, serves and massively spinny loops.... however they are not as dynamic as euro type rubbers in that euro rubbers can have a lot of control, I find them easier to loop underspin with, and then with the right blade and sponge hardness they can still produce good mid distance loops.
It depends on where the gears that you need most are at that makes for a good decision to go with one or the other.
True about the top players in the world being chinese, but those players are lucky being able to just play TT in their lives.
I do agree that the subject wasnt something to argue about.
My friend just kept insisting that his chinese equipment was better than my Euro/Jap set up and kept insulting it.
i told him i preferred it but being a good stubborn friend ignored what ive said.
Even though ive finally beaten him w/ my new set up, he still insists the chinese stuff was better.Thanks guys
Fantastic!
Beat him up some more.
But fortunate for me not to have such a friend who seems to be as stubborn as a mule.
Good fortune for you.
i agree speedplay.
My placement has improved greatly after i upgraded FROM chinese rubbers.
Playing w/ euro/jap made me understand what people talked about the "GEARS" of a rubber.
i improved so much, i think i am ready for my first tournament which is going to be in Lakeland,Fl.
A funny thing is that a lot of really good Chinese players use a tacky chinese rubber on their forehand and a Euro/Jap rubber on their backhand.
And many of the professional chinese players who have come to Houston to coach use Butterfly rubbers.
As everyone say, it really depends on your preference.
I have used both Jap rubbers (Sriver, Sriver EL, Tackifire), Euro (Tibhar Intra) and Chinese (729 Fx, 2000-Tack speeds), chinese rubbers are still the ones for me.In terms of quality.
I think Japanese & Euro rubbers are way ahead of chinese rubbers (in terms of rubber life, durability etc.
).However, for a person who's just picking up the sport, I recommend the person to use chinese rubbers because its cheap.
After the person have discovered his playing style, he can then decide to move on to better and more expensive rubbers.
I am totally sold out on the IQUL 2.2 rubbers in 42 degree sponge.
They cost just 16 dollars and at least for me are much better than the more expensive Srivers and Mark Vs.
I also find them to be fast, spinny and great for the short game.
On the other hand this does not mean that Chinese is better than Euro/Jap, just that this particular product is a very good one, as are many other Chinese products.

They are all good, or bad, players have their preferences and for a player who loves Euro equipment, that is the best, etc.I have just tried two Chinese products for the first time, a 5 dollar 729 FX rubber, and from the way it played, I think its an incredible steal at this price.
The other rubber I tried out on a very hard Chinese Real blade is the Blutenkirsche Tokyo rubber.
It seemed very tacky out of the box, but that wore off fast, and now it plays pretty much like a grippy rubber.
Again a decent Chinese product.
The Euro/Jap rubbers usually last longer, usually are uniform with few if any quality control issues.
But if the only factor was playablity, I am sure many Chinese rubbers are as good or better than Euro/Jap rubbers.
Better in fact if the factor was playablity to cost ratio.
I have a new club mate, in St. Joseph's Winter Haven Table Tennis Club, telling me that chinese rubbers are ideal for the younger players because it makes them work more.
I do agree with him, may it be looping underspin, emphasis on spin, or having to rely more on your technique to create speed.
He mentioned that he prefers european rubbers because he is an older gentleman and doesnt have the bone and joints for the dynamics of creating his own speed.
Although chinese equipment do have quality issues, it comes with it with the cheap price tag.
I came up with the conclusion that chinese rubbers tend to make you focus on technique more than euro/jap style rubbers, although we all SHOULD focus on our techniques rather than equipment.
Would you agree w/ my conclusion?Of course a player's preference is a major factor too since it is only my opinion
Well, I used both, I would say Bryce feels harder, lower throw, works particularly well in power looping and punch-blocking.
Not so well in loading lots of spin unless you have a strong wrist action.Sriver EL is a bit more all-around in usage, probably a bit slower.
It have a better ball bite, so it's a bit easier to feel the ball when making it spin.

I'm just now putting a sheet of Hexer on my blade with Genius on the other side.I'll post some comparison details late this week.
Thanks jevansau.
Please don´t leave me waiting too long
The rubbers are very similar.
I found the Hexer a touch harder, but this could be just because the Genius is a few months old.
In general though, I could just play the same shots for the same results with either rubber.
The Genius was also slightly lighter, but only a couple of grams.
Thx.
In terms of spin, which could produce more, especially when serving?
I'm not sure but hexer felt a bit harder and a bit spinnier to me...
But genius is still very spinny rubber for a tensor...
I tried both rubbers briefly, not a long time ago and I like Genius better than Hexer.
Genius did felt lighter but i think it was just a bit harder though.
Hexer was better on serves and loops, but i didn't feel comfortable hitting with it nor blocking, it seemed like it was really springy and some of my shots were not consistent enough.
Genius i had more control and better hitting, but just a little less spiny.
I would get Genius because it had more control and similar spin and speed to Hexer.
Barracuda (Red Max on a Viscaria blade) felt a lot softer than Tenergy 64 or 05 and was markedly slower, I thought it was too slow.
It felt mushy/soft compared to T64 (but I prefer somewhat harder feel, these days I use T05).
It was very spinny, pretty high throw, but it was difficult to use off the table, as if the thing couldn't stand up to the pressure of hard looping even from second position.
Decent feel on blocks, excellent touch for serving, but it has a kind of weird non-linearity to it that made it feel quite erratic; it is as if it is missing the middle gears.
In short, it has some of the qualities of Tenergy but falls short in almost every respect.
Petermoo has a review on this forum, he basically found it to be too slow.

I assumed Barracuda would be the same as Hexer, but it is not, Hexer is better on my blade and in my hands, harder, a bit faster, a bit more like Tenergy, still not as good (and almost as expensive).Xiom Vega pro may be another story.
Comments on the other thread make it sound really promising, especially given price.
My experience with Boost rubbers is too short to be of much use.
I bought a sheet once, put it on my blade, played with it for five minutes, hated it, took it off, gave it to somebody.
I can barely remember why, can't remember which of the two versions it was.

I find the Hurricane 2 quite durable though, as long as you keep it clean and keep the plastic on.
What do you think is worn out?
Tackwise same, may be SP has more.
But for some reason it's less spinny than H2.

Comparing Transcend SP (red) and H2 blue sponge (black):- SP is heavier - H2 BS is lighter than commercial H2- SP is much more durable- SP is faster, at least this is what I remember- H2 BS has a more suple topsheet = easier to loop(?
)If I'll remember more info I'll post it.I wonder why RITC hasn't come up with a better version of the Transcend sponge.
They didn't released anything impressive for the post glue era.
Both rubbers are slow.
SP is spinnier than H2 com by quite a bit.
I have SP on my HK (only ever practiced with it once and put it down).
It looped nicely and if I had tried it a couple of years ago may have loved it.
I was already into my Gergely and Andro by the time I got to it and well...there is simply no comparison!
H2 com I used for a while a couple of years ago and it was ok, loops were not as spinny as SP and I think it might have been a little slower even (from memory).
Thanks for the input.
I used to use andro Roxon 450 in 2.0 mm, but I found them to be too difficult for me to play consistently with, but that was about a year ago.
Since then I've also used gambler outlaw in 2.2 mm and found that to be comfortable to control with good speed, but I feel like my game has improved the most from using H2.
I wouldn't mind using a faster rubber, in fact I have given a lot of thought into using outlaw again.
Its just that I've started to really like high spin rubbers and wanted to see if SP transcend was worth trying out  .
Me and a friend were comparing Platin and Boost TS on a Sardius and there wasn't much similarity .TS feels softer and slower.
Sinus Alfa felt closer to the TS(on the same wood) but we still liked the Sinus Alfa better.
Platin is faster and harder and better on the short came, lower throw.
Question of taste as to which you will prefer, both are good rubbers.

Platin is way faster than Boost.Both spin the ball but in different ways, TS has considerably more dwell time and sponge is softer.I like Boost TP which is a bit more forgiving and have just ordered TX to try.Petermoo
TX is even better.
Didn't try it on a hard carbon blade though.
Well I've played with Boost TS max for three days now and I can say that this isn't the rubber for me.
It's a really great rubber but it doesn't suit my style of play and stroke.

I used it in my FH and I often go for a killer with my first FH-attack, but I didn't get the same response with TS as I did from Platin since I have a pretty "thick" contact with the ball which needs a bit harder rubber.
Baracuda is pretty different from lets say platin and lack that catapulteffect that platin has.
However, it's REALLY spinny, spinnier than tenergy and with a rather high throw.
It is slow compared to platin but still it's not a slow rubber.
I would probably put the speed just below tenergy which I personally feel is quite a slow rubber because the lack of catapult.

Hi 5minIs there any chance you are referring to me or Kouros because if you are you are absolutely right we both liked the Roxon series but can not understand all the fuss regarding the the tenergy rubbers they are just totally different animals in both feel & spin.

Sorry Vincent I can not compare them for you because I just never persist with tenergy on my FH for more than a couple of minutes before moving on, this is mainly because I do not need a looping machine as I am more of a hitter so much of its appeal is lost on me.
Don't get me wrong I can control it and hit with it (its nowhere as fast as I am am used to) but it just does not feel right for my short game.
Its obviously a great rubber otherwise why would it be so popular.
I've not used the various Roxons, but have used many other Tensors in the Donic product line, which are probably similar, and also Joola Express One and Express two and Xiom Omega III.
The Donics I've used include Platin, Platin soft, Gold, and F1.
I have used Tenergy 05 and 64 on my forehand.
Right now I am playing with Tenergy 64.

I use all of them on a Butterfly Viscaria (a soft carbon-arylate), I play close and middle distance and use short pips on my backhand, and try to attack as much as possible with my forehand.As has been said, they are very different classes of rubber.
(Of course, there is a lot of variation within the class of Tensors, but some generalizations can be made).
Both Tenergy's are much spinnier than any Tensor I have used and have a much higher throw.
The hard sponged Tenrors are vastly superior for short game, especially returning serve, they will feel crisper when hitting.
The Tenergy series are spin monsters when looping.
You just need to make a little effort to try to get top spin on the ball and the thing will be loaded.
And that is what they are for.
That is why very strong players tend to like them, because they are looking to hit heavy topspin whenever it is an option, and they want to be ab le to do it with different paces.
They are not great for everything.
They are not ideal for everybody, and i have had to take some time to get it into my head what they allow me to do.
This is not to say that Tenergy series are quite good for blocking, they feel about the same as Tensors.
They hit ok, not as well as crisply or as explosively as Tensors.
They are definitely a liability for return of serve and push.
But they can pack topspin like I have never seen before and they have a lot of gears when you are spinning.
It has given me a slow loop that wins lot of points and I feel like I didn't do much.
As time goes on, I am learning to deal with their weaknesses.Tenergy 64 is distinctly softer than 05 but it never bottoms out.

The hard Tensors will never bottom out either, but soft ones like F2 or F3, and I suspect Jo Silver, will frequently have that problem.Tenergy rubbers are distincly heavier, 05 being by far the heaviest.
It may put you off, depending on what kind of blade you use and how sensitive you are to this.
It was the thing about 05 that I didn't like, I think, though, I might give it another try.
All Tensors are fragile, but the newest ones are not quite so bad.
Tenergy 64 is also fragile!
Look at it the wrong way and it crumbles or tears around the edges.
I think 05 MAY be more durable.
But none of these SGE rubbers are going to last very long.
I meant to say that Tenergy rubbers and Tensor rubbers both have a nice feel when blocking.
They are equal in my mind.
It wasn't clear in my last post because of bad editing.
Well, if they aren't really comparable, which rubbers seem to suit which part of the game more?

Both Baal and Mars63 put it quite nicely; experienced quite the same thing with Donic (Gold/Silver/Platin), Xiom (Omega II/III), Andro (Roxon 450) and Butterfly (Tenergy 05/25/64).They really seems to work differently, feel differently.
Hitting is quite a lot better with the Tensors, I would agree.
Looping is just average compared to Tenergy.Most of the Tensors I've played with were a bit easier to block with, spin didn't bite as much, I think.

Tenergy - excellent: spin, serve, serve return, durability - blocking and chop ok - more difficult smash - heavier - play satisfactorily in colder temperaturesESN Tensors: average spin, very poor durability - blocking and chop ok - easy smash - lighter - play absolutely unsatisfying in colder temperatures (I was trying for couple of months Roxon 500pro, Platin, Express 1)
I agree with most of this, but "average spin" for Tensors?
Most tensors with below 45 degree sponge, which is the majority of them, have quite good spin...probably more than most Japanese rubbers.
and also in any humidity.
The ball just falls off German rubbers

pretty much all tensors below 45 deg will spin better than a similar hardness japanese/chinese rubber imo.Above, the japanese are probably a bit better, and then the chinese again.Of course, this is a bit of a generalisation...
The Palio Macro ERA is a Tensor and that gives me plenty of spin, even in the 47.5 degree max sponge.
The smashing is indeed easy and loaded with power.
Hi Mars, no, I'm not referring to you or Kouros.
I'm just referring to you.
;pI must admit that I start like Tenergy 05 more and more... Basically because I hurt my wrist (???).
I know you'll be like "what the hell has this got to do liking Tenergy"?

Well, I hurt my wrist from last Wed and haven't really recovered so these couple of days I had to force myself to use more arm movement (which is a good thing) and it resulted in more hit driven spins (i.e.
I rely my arm movement to 'hit' the ball but change the bat angle to spin 'mode' JUST before or ON contact).
The ball then really explodes with speed and spin...
It makes power loop much easier.
I'll try to do that to you on Sat (if you are there and I still remember how to do it...)Another good thing is durability...
I accidental hit my bat into the metal net stand today... it was quite hard but only resulted in a line mark on the edge of Tenergy 05.
If this was on other tensors, it must have been a tear.

That's probably what makes it more durable than other tensors.

Hello!

Might be the difference which is affecting your aim when hitting hard, when it's softer than expected.
Very nice review, thanks Metallikviper!
Very nice review!

A guy I regularly play with, who's been playing for probably 45-50 years and used to be a junior champion many decades ago tried the Outlaw and thought it was o.k., but also experienced a quick decline in performance and major tears around the edge, even on a really light nick on the table.

He had to replace it after about a month of play.To contrast, I caught my Palio Macro ERA on the table tonight, pretty hard, and while it got scraped on the topsheet, not even close to a tear, and you'd have to look really close at it to even notice.
Made me very glad I didn't have the Outlaw, because from what I saw of his rubber I know it would have been ruined.
On slower hits they felt about the same but on really fast hits the T64 seemed to be softer than the Outlaw (maybe that's just me).
However I once used a Timo Boll ALC with Tenergy 05 on the FH which they say is harder than the T64 and it was absolutely horrendous for smashing.

I know it wasn't the same blade but the ALC is very control oriented and sometimes you know when a rubber is just not right for you.Thanks.I don't even dare to play a shot if I think I might even graze the table or a barrier.
I just chose to lose the point.
Call me cheap, but I know the minute I make contact with anything other than the ball on the Outlaw that is $14 down the drain.
And from my experience even heavy contact with the ball over 3 weeks has a similar effect  .
I don't know if you have played with the T64 before but how does it compare to the Palio Macro Era 42.5 or 47.5 deg (preferably from a smashing and loop driving point of view).My pleasure.
Hope it helps.
I have not played with Tenergy at all, so I can't give you a comparison.
Love the Palio, will be sticking with that for a long time.
Hey MV, I now have 5 small tears on my red outlaw 2.0 and they are all along the last 1 or so cm along the edge of the rubber, so the hitting portion of the rubber is still fine.
I don't have any problems with bubbles or broken pips in the hitting area.EDIT: Outlaw would never work on my FH for how I open right now.
I would have to be a mid-distance powerlooper to get the most out of Outlaw on my FH and I am simply not goos enough to play that style yet.
999 on a mid soft spong is it until I run into something else under $20 that works my way.
I think Outlaw has a manufactors fault and you should ask for your money back lol
I wish they would honor it.
But, at this point seeing how well the Outlaw has performed if they even fix their durability issues I would be a happy customer.
BTW the sheet out of the packaging looks absolutely beautiful.

they're both fine on pretty much all blades.EL is just something like 5% harder than FX - and hence has a slightly higher top end/spin.
So you would lose a little control but gain some extra speed when using the EL ?
Not always.
I find the hard sponge= less control thing to be garbage a lot of the time.
The FX will provide extra mech.
spin, however it will touchy in the short game.
Mercury is tackier and slower, and has a slower Chinese sponge.
The Venus is only mildly tacky and has both a faster topsheet and a more springy Japanese sponge.The Superr Soft is slower but with more control.
Throw of the venusis probably a little lower and is less sensitive to incoming spin.

It really comes down to technique... if you're hitting off the end you need to adjust your stroke to make it dropon... like brush the ball 'up' more than forwards, which will make it spinnier and make it drop more.
Is Venus literally better than Mercury in A LOT of ways?Which one would be better for a OFF+ setup?

If you have a fast carbon blade that has a natural low throw, than dont pair it up with a low throw rubber.If the balls going long you can change your stroke simply by closing the angle or taking shorter swings, adding more top helps with it to land on.Personally I like the venus over the mercury.
I do not have a carbon blade, I have a Donic Opticon RS, which is very quick.What do you recommend now?
I use Venus on the TBS, a carbon/arlyte blade and can't get enough of the "low" throw.
Sorry to throw wrenches around your thoughts.
Why not give venus a try for yourself.
A sheet of it doesn't exactly cost an arm and a leg and it does a lot of the same stuff Bryce did so well.
Just be sure to break it in before forming opinions.
Ill say the venus
I use Venus for counter hitting with no problem.
However, when you say your shots keep going long, changing rubber is not the way to fix it.
If the rubber is high throw, you close the blade more to compensate.You can change your stroke to go into the ball more.
Do they go long because they fly in a straight line without much arc?
That is your tecnique, not the rubber.
I can switch bats with someone with a totally different rubber with different throw and in a short time, (one minute?)
be hitting the table.I would not start chaseing the "Magic" rubber.
If you have trouble with a slow rubber, faster rubber will not help no matter what the throw is.
I'm not asking for tips about my backhand, just asking for a comparison between these two rubbers.

Sorry about that, it's just that I am already working on my backhand, and it is improving, but I am not changing my rubber solely for trying to improve me backhand.But, yes, thank you all anyway, my question has basically been answered.

I never thought i would welcome a lunatic, but here we go: Welcome to the forum, lunaticbulbul.
I am afraid, I can not compare these rubbers as I have not played Higher III.
Until someone who might have played both comes along and answers you post, you could go to the Equipment review index and read reviews about them.

After that you get a feeling for what they are like and how they compare in general.729-08 reviewviewtopic.php?t=4790Higher III reviewsviewtopic.php?t=669viewtopic.php?t=852viewtopic.php?t=1322If you read these, you will get a very good idea, IMHO .Good luck, lunatic
729-8 has a thinner, tackier topsheet and a harder sponge.
Higher III is soft for a Chinese rubber, average hardness for Jap/Euro.
Higher III is very grippy, maybe just a tiny bit tacky.
Both rubbers are very spinny.
Neither is extremely fast.
IMO, (some disagree), Higher is a lot faster than 729-08.
Both are on the heavy side, but not very heavy.
If you like the feel of a traditional Chinese rubber but want a little more speed, try 729-08.
If you tend to play more mid-distance you'd probably prefer Higher III.
If you can't decide don't worry.
The differences aren't so great that you couldn't play with either.
i actually felt the higher 3 sponge is pretty hard ... probably mid hard for a chinese rubber and extremely hard for a japanese sponge rubber.
(higher 3 is jap sponge)its a good rubber.. i would call very good if these new rubbers were not available.
i have an uncut sheet of 729-08 factory-tuned prov version lying with me.. but i haven't cut it and planning to sell .
i decided to stick with bw2 some time... instead of constantly shifting rubbers and screwing my game.
no, it's not more durable.
about the same actually.
T05 has lot more spin and speed is about same.
they're pretty different rubbers.
Yes the speed is in the same general range but they don't play the same at all.
BSFX has quite a low throw, is slightly faster, and a good bit lighter.
05 is much higher throw and for most people produces a lot more spin.
Of course it also reacts more to spin.
It's also a fairly heavy rubber(almost chinese heavy).

I don't think you quite answered the question.
So is your assessment the same for comparing Roxon 450 and Platin soft?
Slippery would you like to have my other sheet of roxon 450 ?
You can have it really cheap or perhaps switch for some other rubber.
PM if you are interested.
I will report back, but I still is struggling with inverted too so I will need to have 2 active setup`s .
But I have decided to test it soon along with my Tenergy 05 might be a nice setup.
I have not played with Platin, but did play with Roxon 500 2.0mm.
I found it to be surprisingly slow and dead.
I much preferred the Plasma 430 2.0mm with which I able to loop faster and spinnier compared to the Roxon.
Problem with Plasma is that the edges of the rubber break off (chip) very, very easily.
I'm currently playing with Tenergy 05 and like it much more than either the Roxon or Plasma.
Slip, I'll be very keen to hear how Roxon 450 plays on Wavestone.
I came very close to just ordering one of these things to see why you think its so special.
But I backed out of it lol.
Might be still tempted if I know the Tensors do work well on it.
If I'd ordered one, it would have been the new one as it sounds much more to my liking with its balanced feel.
Silly Speedplay!
Of course I have!
I didn't really find much difference between the 450 and the PS in practice.
Could quite easily subsitute one for the other.
I found the difference between the two had the roxon being slightly gripper, but softer than the PS.
Just to reiterate: I'd take the 450 over the PS, but I'd take the Platin over the 500.
I really didn't get along with 500 for some reason...
Me too!
I think its a conspiracy by the TT manufacturers to get rich.
They changed the acceptable price range for rubbers without us even realising!

Different people have different interpretations.
But like most other people, to me takcy=sticky, and grippy is just grippy
To me, sticky/tacky is when you can pick a ball up with it.
Wont pick up a ball?
Grippy.
Could also be Anti, SP, LP or MP Hookshot.
Good point Reb !
Actually Slippery, I never said those things couldn't be grippy.
I merely point out what they could be if they wouldn't hold a ball.
I think your mindset is one of challenge always, but I wasn't necessarily challenging Hookshot, but adding further descriptives.
My understanding was chinese rubbers were sticky and typically had harder sponges.
Whereas Japenese rubbers tended to be tacky usually having softer sponges.
Grippy is a term that can be applied to long or short pips to indicate some chance to generate your own spin, and hence a greater reaction to spin.
Japanese rubbers aka BTY rubbers are generally only grippy in my experience Anti.
Tackiness chop really isn't tacky.
I think it was when they first invented it, but it changed direction in its development but the kept the name.
I don't think Grippiness Chop would sound so appealing LOL.
To me tacky and sticky are the same thing.
The only difference I might allocate is where one rubber that is tacky holds the ball for a second or two.
A sticky rubber might hold it for a minute or never let it go without some influence.
Are very important in e-mail as tone cannot be read.
There, you are not now last post in this thread speedy.
BTW, i know what you mean re- pet peeves!
Yep that's how I interpret is as well...
I usually use plastic sheet to determine (non-adhesive)... if it sticks (really sticks) it's tacky, otherwise it's grippy or non-grippy...
That's a great acid test Haggisv!
Place a plastic film, something that not sticky like a one sided glue sheet sorta thing, more of a projector sheet.
Place it on a tacky rubber and it sticks and removes all the air bubbles,
place it on a grippy rubber straight out of the packet like a almana or a sriver and the sheet simply falls off.
As for tacky vs grippy - that a question that won't be answered as it's more up to the individual prefrence of choice.
I think he meant whether people prefer to use tacky or grippy rubbers is a matter of personal preference...
so im guessing that the geospin tacky its tacky as in sticky as in able to pick up the ball?????
and in pick up the ball do you mean that when i press the rubber against the ball on the table it sticks to the rubber like scotch tape?
That means when i play, i just need to hold my bat still and let the balls curve into my rubber and then all i need to do is move my hand forward??
Real problem is all the balls from the other courts keep coming in to yours.
Good way to collect balls for multiball though.
haha yeah, well seriousl, when it comes to picking up balls, what is the difference between tacky/sticky or grippy?
TELL ME!
No need to yell Lehman.
A tacky rubber will pick up a ball to some degree, be it a second or a minute.
A grippy one won't.
haha thnx reb,
sry.
but well on the packaging of my rubber it says that it produces astounding "mechanical" spin.
what is mechanical spin?
is it just a posh term to describe spin?
Mechanical spin means it's grippy, not tacky.
Speed: Roxon 500, JO Gold.
COR/COR2 maybe.Spin: Roxon 450, Platin.
Tenergy is pretty hard compared to most Tensors, with little dwell time.
The feel is quite different.
The hardness of Tenergy is about comparable to JO Coppa Gold from Donic (which is one of the harder Tensors).
Gold is a little faster, Tenergy is spinnier and has a much higher throw angle.
Tenergy felt A LOT heavier.
I suspect that Tensors like Joola Express 1, are more or less like JO Gold.
Platin is pretty hard too.
Most other Tensors are very much softer.
None of these rubbers, Tenergy included, are much like Chinese sponge.
I suspect the versions of Tenergy that will come out later (and that are currently being used by some pro players) such as Tenergy 25 and Tenergy 64 will be more like Chinese sponge.
A Tensor that might appeal to Chinese sponge users is Donic F1 HS (HS stands for Hard Sponge version).
It is said to be designed that kind of player.
In the interests of full disclosure, that is based on the Donic description, I have not tried it myself.
hmm, how about soft tensors?
i very much like the feel of it.
F1 regular is pretty soft.
So is JO Silver and JO Platin SOft.
F2 is even softer still.
If you want something positively mushy, you could try F3 or F3 Big Slam.
All of these are from Donic, all are tensors, and I suspect most of the other companies have essentially equivalent stuff under a different name.
I happen to have tried more of the Donic rubbers since they made the first tensor that I ever used (the old F1).
All of the above will feel soft and light coming off of Chinese sponge.
I use JO Gold now.
It is relatively hard.
I like everything about it except its durability.

I can only speak to IQ UL and unfortunately can't compare to any of the rubbers you listed--so this may be utterly worthless.
But I'm currently madly in love with IQ ultralight on my BH.
I play a close to the table style and need a BH rubber that allows me to block with good speed, receive serves, and put some kick into loops.
Since I use tackier chinese rubbers on FH that tend to be much heavier, I was looking for a light, grippy (non-tacky) rubber with good speed when I needed it.
IQ UL seems to be that rubber--again, at least for me.
I have it in 1.8 thickness with a 40 deg sponge and am loving it.
Previous BH rubbers that the IQ UL replaced included Focus III, LKT Pro XT, Palio CJ8000 36-38 sponge, Cream on MRS, and regular old 729 w/ blue sponge.

Is this true?
I'm also interested in Donic/Nittaku JOW and Nodias, but weight is a concern if they weigh similar to traditional Chinese rubbers.
Would be great if they weigh similar to Sriver.
The weight is that made with to think to a nontacky setup.
If the weight of Coppa or Nittaku JOW are around the chinese rubbers there is not much deal though ...
If you're looking to drop the weight significantly from your current set-up, then you prob.
should consider other rubbers, or slightly thinner sponge.

not sure what you're talking about my sheets of nittaku jo max weight 41 gms per sheet.
Vali, looks like you've found the rubber you're looking for.
I read about some variation between Nittaku's and Donic's; I guess Nittaku's is lighter?
I thought it was the other way around.
I hope so.
I always thought that Nittaku rubbers are heavy.
Can compare Donic JO Waldner with Coppa in 2mm / 2.1mm black.
JO is lighter despite having a harder sponge.
This is due to it having a thinner topsheet than the Coppa.
41g for 2mm cut black JO is about right (40 to 42g variation).
Red JO plays harder.

Comparing Coppa to JO is a bit like comparing Sriver EL to Sriver L ...... its a bit slower and softer and is better for over the table pushes than JO but JO has better speed and punch and is very good for BH loop.
They are similar but not the same.
Coppa comes in more like 43g cut sheet (red or black) and has a slightly higher arc than JO.
I like JO on BH; Coppa more on FH.

I am using LKT Pro XT at the moment, (I prefer tacky rubbers and maintain the tackiness with Spinmax) and it is very light compared to Globe999nat for example...

Massive response...

This Spinsonic isn't bad actually takes a bit of getting use to ... what I've found with the super priming is that once long life speed glue effect wears off (it lasts ages) there's a large decrease in performance (and I speed glued this thing to bits)
I was waiting for the Skyline follows up
Spintech is either a loopers rubber and I think that is what is was designed for or....
a great choppers - which is what it was not designed for.
Basically its very easy to produce a float with this rubber with little variation in stroke and because the sponge is very soft its highly controllable.
Anyway thats not how I play so I'll be checking out Skyline in detail.
Testing in progress ...
Spintech plays too much like a Euro loopers rubber for my tastes, but it woud be ok for a backhand rubber (but of course that is reserved for pips!)
Anyway keen on keep checking out Skyline - nice power - great power but we'll see how it runs.
Delicate serves bit tricky!
If I was to use it I'd need a game plan around it, which in this case isn't too hard.
For my game Spintech is too slow and I don't like 'looper style' rubber.
The tacky rubbers like skyline are awesome for spinny serves... the main reason I use them!
Yeah you could be right it might produce a strange kind of spin - it could simply be the speed.
I can't see it being spinnier than Geospin T.
What I noticed was the power Skyline produced* and how different it was from Geospin T. on knock about.
My opponent commented that the spin was weird ... but it'll take several weeks before testing is finished.
I dunno.
* I don't know a great deal about inverted (compared to long pips) I've played Bryce FX, Almana Sound, BTY TTS, BTY T Chop and I think thats about all.
Nice.
Quad post
Heh heh fixed...
Geospin T is actually not that tacky, but it IS great for generating spin.
Skyline 2.0mm super primed with long life glue.
Very different from the strong mechanical spin rubbers I am use to.
Fast and spinny but too powerful for my backhand loop against topspin.
I had to punch block this as opposed to loop it.
I could easily get use to this but I think for the time being I'll be sticking with the 1.5mm Skyline version uintil I get use the shift in rubber.
The things I notice with it are:
Feels fast compared to mechnical spin of Geospin T., Almana Sound and Bryce FX (however I played the last two rubbers on an ALL+ blade this was tested on an OFF blade).
Has the extra gear for sure.
Strong brush stroke spin
Medium throwing angle after priming
4 Post priming it was very stable across the blade.
Badly affected by dust - if a rubber good at mechanical spin gets dusty it still spins - with this rubber it drops off the blade
Great forehand but will take some adjusting to play on the backhand
In depth knowledge of inverted is not my thing so I'll leave it there.
The things I noticed about the 1.5mm:
Strong spin, badly affected by dust, etc..
High throwing angle - not much different from Geospin T. This could be that I applied as much glue to the priming as 2.0mm (heaps)
Stable and not as fast be a long way (obviously)
Ok on the backhand
Alls well that ends well and I like it.
Thanks for the update Mathias, and welcome back!!
I was under the impression that Spinsonic SV had a tacky surface on it.
Is that not correct?
Spintech claims that it has both Tacky, and Mechanically spinny topsheet.
It does - it uses a soft sponge so the ball digs into the rubber to allow mechanical spin.
However the sponge is too soft IMO - the ball digs in too quickly and results in a slower speed.
You need much thicker sponge than I was using.
I did speed glue it but haven't checked the results.
See, I'm actually quite good with the sponge being soft.
Speed I don't need.
What I need is high control in a rubber that is able to manipulate discusting amounts of spin on the ball.
Is there any inbuilt speed glue effect to this rubber?
How durable is it?
From Spintech's site it was really expensive.
Is there somewhere that this rubber isn't just ridiculously expensive?
Ok generally I'm quiting forum posting for other reasons (pips forum) but anyway:
Yes this rubber is superb at manipulating spin - for example producing a float (no spin) return from e.g.
heavy topspin is easy with this rubber and yes it gives loads of control.
Normally producing a float with Chinese inverted is hard to perform and in particular control from incoming topspin.
The rubber is officially a 'speed glue rubber', I just found the sponge very soft.
Precisely how it performs once primed I dunno - although I've had one primed for ages.
The reason I didn't like it was because if you are off the table its hard to win a point using a power attack.
However if I was a double inverted player I would certainly use a sheet of rubber of this nature on my backhand, which I could then twiddle with.
Basically if you've pips on one side and this on the other there just isn't any power in the game.
As for price I'm afraid thats as cheap as it gets.
My wife just chnages to Skyline II 1.5mm... she was very impressed witht he control it offered....her whole game imporved a notch overnight
being alex bumped this post up i'll say my 2 cents
spinsonic SV is perfect
yes I know, its caus i use it but its true, many people can see a huge change in my game thanks to the spinsonic, the amount of spin i generate is grea, my sidespin is lethal now.
And now thnaks to a learning of diferent serves, I am starting to become a bit of a tricky player to play.
The weight of spinsonic is great, even with pips on the back my blade is very light (mind you, spintech is know for weight, their Jade SV is one of the fastest and lightest bubbers around imo).
because of the weight, it makes the 3rd ball easier to pick up.
Control is amazing, i can pull off a lot of drop shots now because of teh rubber

Yeah I like Skyline 2 1.5mm (in fact I've just received another sheet today) but a low throw on the backhand is a pain (twiddle), although it provides much closer stroke angle to the pips, which is important.
Skyline 2 is great on the forehand and brilliant for sidespin loops because they stay low and spinny, without over arcing (easier to place and faster).
As I understand things Haggisv - unless I misunderstood - she understands pips.
I would read this as meaning your wife is better than you.
So presumably she now much better than you?
You must have a great defensive forehand.
A classic style of play if you win with speed, very classic.
Sounds to me like priming is a bad idea for the Spinsonic.
That's just going to further soften an already soft sponge.
Possibly just EEII, or CTE, and slap that puppy on the blade.
yea, thats why it suited me, vbecause I have an effective defenceive block that works, when i blokc the anmount of spin it sends back is a good amount.
I just stuck the sucker on teh blade and played.
although i would liek to see how the rubber would play with EEII or CTE
Well, if I run into alot of money someday I'll get it and let you know what it's like with EEII.

Uhmm., bbut but..arghh... maybe...    We're normally about 50/50 against each other, so the new rubber could change this    Against each other it's pretty even which is great for me... but against others in comp I'm well ahead... (hope she doesn't read this  )...
Thank you for pointing this out
IMO Desto F2 is better in any aspect (excepting his fragility).
But that depends on your style.
Desto is a soft tensor and Quattro is more like Sriver but a thicker topsheet.

I should receive a sheet of quattro soon but according what I've red on various forums there is so many types of quattro (thickness, hardness, colour, ...retailer...  )there should be 1 looking like somehow to F2.
All of the Donic F1, F2, and F3 are fragile, they crumble around the sides, but they all have a great feel when playing.
Played yesterday with quattro 2.2 1 side and F1 2.0 other side on acoustic.
Quattro was way slower than F1.
Maybe my "normal gluing" was wrong.
I then put 2 layers of speed glue in order to break'in.
Was much better but still nothing like a desto serie.
I've red quattro needs few gluing before it can deliver it's full potential.
Is that true ?
How could I optimize the rubber w/o speedgluing ?
New formula (2006) are less fragile than formers.
I got 2 sheets of F1 new formula that I play with for 3 mths and they do not crumble...hurray!
Thanks for feedback jolan!
I have heard it takes a few session to break in, the effect gets better...
The Quattro topsheet is a lot thicker and firmer than the quattro, so I would think the feel would be quite differerent...
Did you feel much speed glue effect?
That is good to know too... makes them better value!
Well, can't say yet.
Wouldn't be honest as I've been playing only once with it.
Let's wait saturday for a new session.
What I did is that I removed the sheet, put 2 more layers of speed glue, get it rest, plus 1 layer of normal glue.
Sticked it on my legout and made test in my garage.
Wow, nothing likes yesterday !
It is alive !
fast, bouncy and crispy.
Is it speedglue or has it broken in ?
To be continued...
Adding some glue is often simiular to breaking it in, so I suspect the effect will be a little of both... No doubt it won't be quite as lively without glue though, so don't get your hopes up too high
I have gone through several sheets of new Formula F1 since they came out with it.
It most definitely crumbles around the edges but a little less than the original version.
The new version plays well, but I preferred the original F1 Desto a little bit in terms of the overall "speed glue" like effect.
Overall it is a great rubber.
I have a sheet of Desto F2 and is remarcably soft but very bouncy and speedy.
Great spin and nice medium-low throw.
Indeed the topsheet is fragile ,if you accidentally hit the table(like me  ) it is possible to damage the topsheet ( with Globe 999 it is possible to damage the table ...).
However even the Donic said speed-glueing is not recommanded I had no problems using Tibhar Rapid Clean .
LOL, I like that!!
That's true .
Once accidentally I hit the table and take off the white paint from it.
The rubber was OK.
Definetely the Globe 999 National is a great and durable rubber.
Well, I had my second session with IQ.
Very different from the 1st.
Still a bit dissatisfaying.
Speed is here at last but surprinsingly hard to control.
On current shots (drives, blocks) it's still on the slow side.
Let's imagine sriver fx with 1 thin layer of speed glue.
Then you start looping and wow here comes Mambo with 2 big layers of SG.
Spin is still missing.
Weight is low for a 2.2 thick sheet.
In brief and in order to stick to the topic, it has nothing to with desto F2.
I'll keep testing it for a while cause I suspect it to be a new evolutive generation of rubber.
It grows and changes every time you play it until it reaches its adult form.
Just feed it with glue and dress it with diff blades untill it finds its match...

thread_title: Joola rhyzer 43 an improvement or worth buying? Help me pick

thread_title: Opinions about Tibhar MX-S for FH or BH

I cannot say anything about Moristo SP as my experience with SPs has been short and not as successful as with inverted .

I don't really like SPs much.My post is on Moristo DEF, the inverted rubber.For me it has been a great discovery.At present I am playing in 1.2 mm and I can defend and attack consistently.Plenty of spin on serves when needed, great control in chops and blocks.With Grubba all + I have enough speed to attack with quality and safely.Of course, my set up is not a rocket but the control with good speed is there .

Also , when I twiddle on the bh the control makes all the shots safe and with great placement.The only drawback is the price, yes, ...not cheap.That's why in my free time I try to find a cheap replacement ,however, I like it so much I doubt i will change it during this season .If any players do like soft thin sponges on the fh plus spin plus good control in chops and blocks, Moristo Def will not let you down .
It is a safe bet

thread_title: Palio HK1997 gold or 729 Bloom Power
reply_split: People tend to think that it helps to spin the ball.

thread_title: Palio HK1997 gold or 729 Bloom Power
reply_split: Yes sure it does, so why not all rubbers are made tacky!?

thread_title: Palio HK1997 gold or 729 Bloom Power
reply_split: Jap style rubbers, for example Palio AK47 red or blue, would spin your ball not less than tacky STN, but these are just "grippy" top sheets and not sticky at all.Sure you know it better than me that tackiness in Chinese classic rubbers is to compensate for the otherwise short dwell time because of hard sponge.

thread_title: Palio HK1997 gold or 729 Bloom Power
reply_split: Did you notice that if top sheet is not tacky then it will not have hard sponge.

thread_title: Palio HK1997 gold or 729 Bloom Power
reply_split: And opposite, if there is hard sponge then topsheet is made tacky to win back some dwell time.

thread_title: Palio HK1997 gold or 729 Bloom Power
reply_split: So what I am trying to say here that when we choose to go for tacky Chinese rubbers we normally want to get that hard sponge on the racket, tackiness comes as extra little bonus.

thread_title: Palio HK1997 gold or 729 Bloom Power
reply_split: Our playing style then different - full body rotation, power from your hips and etc (ask boxer does he hit using hand power or hips and torso power?

thread_title: Palio HK1997 gold or 729 Bloom Power
reply_split: You might be very surprised ...) Similar mechanics here.

thread_title: Palio HK1997 gold or 729 Bloom Power
reply_split: If we want to use Chinese classic sponge we do full swing shots to bend that hard sponge and make it work.

thread_title: Palio HK1997 gold or 729 Bloom Power
reply_split: Tiny wrist/elbow motions are not powerful enough to do that.So 1) if you are not doing any of that or not purposely learning towards these skills and 2) putting Chinese rubbers on your blade because of tackiness cause it helps to spin the ball, take it easy and go for soft sponge but grippy topsheet.

easier than with T05.

I would look into Friendship/729 rubbers - Focus 3 Snipe, probably.
Hi,I'm assuming that you're currently using the old/original Palio AK47....
The newer variants, ie.
AK47 Red, Yellow Sponge, Blue are a lot lighter...

The Yellow Sponge, is the heaviest of the 3, but is still lighter than the old/original AK47.The newer Red, Yellow, Blue variants, differ in speed, and hardness... Red, being the hardest and fastest, and Blue being the softest.
Yellow sits between the Red & Yellow...
I've tried the Yellow, and Blue, and I quite like both, as long as they're paired with a blades that're on the stiffer side...
I second Ziv's suggestion of the Focus III Snipe...
It comes in different sponge hardness...
I'm using one (On another setup) that has a sponge hardness of 39° - 41° ... You could also check-out various rubbers by LKT/KLT, Yinhe, and other Chinese brands...
They all have inexpensive, and some light-weight options.
Just be mindful that a light rubber will not play the same as a heavy one.
Usually the light ones have a softer sponge, which will play differently.
Yasaka Shining Dragon is a mid-hard rubber but much lighter than Chinese stuff.
Only problem is removing rubber from blade ... you HAVE TO USE Nailpolish Remover or Acetone to remove it, else the topsheet will separate from the sponge from the slightest tension of pulling it.
Go for 729 OEM ... or 729 SuperFX ( FX-C if u want slower ).
Thanks folks- my current AK47 has red/peach sponge and yellow sponge.
Perhaps I will just change the yellow sponge for something different.

Plenty of lighter Chinese sheets.
These are light:KTL Pro-XT "Green Dragon" black 47.77g	163x167mm	0.177g/cm^2KTL Pro-XT black 53.23g	166x168mm	0.193g/cm^2Iskandar
That's odd (or is it ?
given how inconsistent some these Chinese products are) ...
If I recollect correctly, mine weighed around 53 gms.
uncut... Could not weigh, just the rubber, post cutting, since it's glued to the blade, and then cut.
But, we could shave-off a min.
of 8-10gms (I have a larger blade head)..
So, at less than 45gms cut, I'd say, it's still quite light, comparatively.
Then, if the weight:performance, is taken into consideration, the rubber is well worth-it
It's not just "Chinese products" that are inconsistent.
Have a look in Haggis's rubber sheet weight database (kinda too lazy to get you a URL right now) and you'll see that even expensive Japanese and German sheets vary a lot in weight.
German sheets can be pretty heavy, too.
Only a year or so ago people were complaining that Nexy Karis sheets had HUGE weight differences, and that's a $50 sheet.
Iskandar

If you're in the mood to try something different...
Actually, I'd say MOST Chinese rubbers are of really good quality.
There ARE a few with QC problems, most notably those KTL Gold Star sheets I bought a couple years back.
And Palio - the new AK47s seem OK quality wise but their older sheets were really hit and miss.
Prices are low because - well, Chinese goods can be made at a low price for various reasons.
Which is why Apple makes its I-Phones in China.
Iskandar

Personally, I've bought loads of Chinese rubbers/blades/balls, and have almost never faced issues with the blades nor rubbers.. My statement is based, mostly on feedback from clubmates, and/or other players... More recently, with the 729 Focus III Snipe rubber...
I have one (Black 39°-41°), and there's nothing wrong with it, and it plays amazing.

.. On the other hand, a fellow club-mate bought the same one in Red, around the same time, and it plays kind of weird - The ball seems to just slip of the rubber...I've found major inconsistencies with the balls - More recently, with DHS D40+ (Ding Ning on the box) ...
I bought a box of 10, around a week back, which seems to look and play, differently from lots, I had purchased 3-6 months back...
The newer lot balls, seem whiter, have more bounce (here, I find inconsistencies within balls of the same lot itself), and feel heavier..
https://www.aliexpress.com/store/202364 ... rchText=61 61 Seconds products, a grear variety of sponges/ topsheets.Be happy.
Of all those rubber abundance, I do prefer those 42* stiff sponges to offer me a true dynamical linearity.
Yes.
Dynamical Linearity means a minimum of Catapultive effects.
I hate those sudden ball projections on my rubber.
Mind you, they are a little slower than a lot of other Chinese rubbers (even the Green Dragon).
I suspect Red Dragon would be about as light, and is nontacky, so it might be faster than the Green Dragon.Iskandar

thread_title: Backhand rubber - Sanwei T-88 Taiji/Palio Aeolus/neither?

thread_title: Backhand rubber - Sanwei T-88 Taiji/Palio Aeolus/neither?

thread_title: Modern rubber with THIN sponge 1.0mm or less?
reply_split: Here's why I think such rubbers don't exist.

thread_title: Modern rubber with THIN sponge 1.0mm or less?
reply_split: These "modern rubbers" are designed to do what?

thread_title: Modern rubber with THIN sponge 1.0mm or less?
reply_split: Make lots of spin and generate high speed.

thread_title: Modern rubber with THIN sponge 1.0mm or less?
reply_split: You do that by, um, boosting the sponge, coming up with the optimal pips arrangement, optimizing the chemical composition of the topsheet, etc.

thread_title: Modern rubber with THIN sponge 1.0mm or less?
reply_split: etc.

thread_title: Modern rubber with THIN sponge 1.0mm or less?
reply_split: etc.

thread_title: Modern rubber with THIN sponge 1.0mm or less?
reply_split: And why use thick sponge?

thread_title: Modern rubber with THIN sponge 1.0mm or less?
reply_split: Exactly the same reasons - you want lots of spin and more speed.

thread_title: Modern rubber with THIN sponge 1.0mm or less?
reply_split: So to get as much spin and speed as possible, you combine the thick sponge AND all the technology you have.

thread_title: Modern rubber with THIN sponge 1.0mm or less?
reply_split: So why use all this technology with thin sponge?

thread_title: Modern rubber with THIN sponge 1.0mm or less?
reply_split: You've just thrown away half of what you need to get what you wanted to achieve in the first place.

thread_title: Modern rubber with THIN sponge 1.0mm or less?
reply_split: And besides, if you make a Tensor with 1.0mm sponge, it'll be the equivalent of, say, Sriver with 1.3mm sponge.

thread_title: Modern rubber with THIN sponge 1.0mm or less?
reply_split: Why bother making the Tensor with 1.0mm sponge to begin with?

thread_title: Modern rubber with THIN sponge 1.0mm or less?

thread_title: Modern rubber with THIN sponge 1.0mm or less?
reply_split: they must have done a sloppy job...the procedure how i did it before was:you smear a little glue evenly on the glass, little more than the size of the rubber, and than gently lower the pimpled side of the backside on it so only tops of the pimple are touching the glue...that way you will not get the glue between the pimples...than glue the sponge to the blade and than glue the top of the sponge that is going on pimple side of the backside...leave it all dry and than gently put the pimpled side of the backside that you glued to the sponge and press it firmly.

thread_title: Modern rubber with THIN sponge 1.0mm or less?

Of the rubbers they stock and that I've used the one that has characteristics most similar to Marder 2 would be Dr Neubauer Domination.
But it's quite expensive.
TBH many of the classic rubbers play very similar despite being slightly less tacky.
So, no spinlord products in the US?
All I can see is an email address:https://spinlord-tt.de/welcome/distributors/
Thanks, and they reached out and said no distributors in the US, so back to the question of a medium hardness, medium tack rubber for chopping.
Preferably not too expensive.
DHS Hurricane 3-50 soft.
Medium soft sponge, bit tacky, not to expensive.
Thank you!
May I make a suggestion that's from out in left field?
TinArc 5.
Turns out to be quite different from TinArc 3, fairly soft sponge.
I was trying it out as a forehand rubber and I now mainly use it on the backhand (which I think it was designed for) because it was a fair amount slower than I thought it'd be.
AND it makes a decidedly "THUNK" sound when you hit the ball.
It's in the $20 range more or less on AliExpress (including shipping), price varies quite a bit (there's a major sale coming in 3-4 days), and it won't break the bank.
Definitely cheaper than Tenergy at any rate...  Iskandar

A couple more non tensor rubbers I have used that may work for you are:Xiom Musa 1.5/1.8 blackGewo return drive 1.7mm blackThe Musa is medium hard in feel with a lowish throw and low tack whilst the Gewo is a bit softer and slightly tacky.
Both are very linear and suit controlled topspin drives, blocks and chops on balsa or wood blades.
Thank you both for the suggestions!
I really appreciate it!
After t80 fx your attack will suffer badly with the alternatives mentioned on a Defplay imo
Yes classic sponge rubbers like Musa & Gewo return drive need at least an all+ bladeXiom Asia df in 1.8mm is very grippy and good for chopping as well as attacking.
Why is that?

To generate enough pace with the polyball on defense blades for modern defensive one really needs to use a fast rubber.I like both Musa and Gewo on fast balsa blades but on slowish blades not enough pace for forehand attack.

Donic Bluefire JP 01 was used by Shiono for chop/attack on Defplay not so long ago and I noticed a good offer on TTNPP with free delivery,I may try this myself eventuallyI did try Marder 2 on Defplay and the combination did not work for me
That makes sense to me, and with the setup I have, I still do have enough pop, especially with the Tenergy 80fx, which is really lovely on this blade.
I also cut the defplay down to a standard size blade, and it changed a bit.
I am playing Air Defence on the backhand now, and have tried short pips before, which was ok, but I did not find I had the attacking capacity with it as I do inverted.
I do appreciate all the suggestions, so keep them coming!

thread_title: Friendship Focus III Snipe / Palio AK47 Blue
reply_split: Hi, I have used the Focus III extensively 5 years ago and recently bought the AK47 Blue.

thread_title: Friendship Focus III Snipe / Palio AK47 Blue
reply_split: For a direct comparison the AK47 Blue is slightly faster but actually significantly less grip so you are not going to get higher throw from it.

thread_title: Friendship Focus III Snipe / Palio AK47 Blue

Without knowing enough about your level or how long you have been playing or what your playing style is it is hard to give good advice but I will try.
If you like to step away from the table and play loops and topspin drives then the Tenergy is a great rubber for that.
The blade is also a factor.
A good looping blade such as the Nittaku Violin will also be high throw so you need to adjust accordingly.
Maybe you need to stand a bit further back than you already are?
Maybe your technique is the issue?
Faster hand speed will always help the ball curve down more and land on the table.
More brushing, less hitting through the ball.
I am just assuming a lot of things about your game here.If you plan to play a close-to-the-table kind of game, are you saying you want to play a more push block sort of game?
In that case I don't think the Tenergy is the right rubber since it is springy and high throw.
You will need a stiffer racket or a harder sponge, or both for that type of game to work.
T05 is fine for close to the table controlled spin play.
You will need more compact strokes to adjust to the shorter recovery time, that's all.And it's a good general rule to change one thing at a time.
So change your preferred distance now, keep the same equipment.
When you settle in at the new distance, if you still want to change equipment then do it.
That way you will get a clear evaluation of each change.
Thanks for the advance.I played County as a kid and had a low national ranking.
(mid 90s) then had a 10 year break played in local league for a season and won promotion from middle division of 5 to 2nd top (top division contained players from strong British league teams).
Currently back in local league... Making too many mistakes and wanting to push on and get promoted up the divisions.
Using Primorac off- blade
The main drawback of Tenergy 05 is that it's quite sensitive to incoming spin from your opponent.
So if that's the cause of many mistakes, and it outweighs the number of winners you hit, only then it'w worth considering something else.Are you using 2.1mm or 1.9mm?
The blade is certainly good for looping, with tons of control.
I always preferred 64 over 05 for short action/close to the table counterlooping.
But I don't think it was intended for that...
Short pips?
Iskandar

How long you've been playing TT and what is your current level?
