thread_title: Joola Express 1/2 VS Bryce Speed FX
reply_split: I found the Bryce line of rubber to be excellent in this particular usage.

thread_title: Joola Express 1/2 VS Bryce Speed FX
reply_split: I haven't personally tried the Express 1 or 2, so I can't vouch for them.

thread_title: Joola Express 1/2 VS Bryce Speed FX
reply_split: I used Joola Express 1 last season, and it was the fastest rubber around at the time.

thread_title: Joola Express 1/2 VS Bryce Speed FX
reply_split: Very flat throw, with a low spin level make it the opposite of Tenergy.

thread_title: Joola Express 1/2 VS Bryce Speed FX
reply_split: Great for hitting at the table, excellent for pushing (seems to grip well on slow shots), consistent smashes.

thread_title: Joola Express 1/2 VS Bryce Speed FX
reply_split: The downside is the low spin, which makes it hard work for loopers, but for blockers (you have to be good to control it though) and hitters it's excellent.

thread_title: Joola Express 1/2 VS Bryce Speed FX
reply_split: Pretty hard sponge lacks feel (on an Andro Super Core Off+) but gives a positive air to the rubber - it's getting the ball back rather than sinking in.

thread_title: Joola Express 1/2 VS Bryce Speed FX
reply_split: If you're comparing it to Bryce Speed FX then Express 2 is the similar rubber (softer sponge), which will add some spin and feel at the expense of pace.

thread_title: Joola Express 1/2 VS Bryce Speed FX
reply_split: I'm probably changing to Bryce Speed in the close season (May) unless the new toys they bring out look more fun.Also worth considering Andro Hexer - a loss of speed to the 2 above, but very accurate and quite spinny (can lift pushes easily) and plentry of gears.

thread_title: Joola Express 1/2 VS Bryce Speed FX
reply_split: Plays well attacing over the table with all-out top-spin hits, but durability can be an issue if you play more than 10 hours a week.

thread_title: Joola Express 1/2 VS Bryce Speed FX

thread_title: Haifu Shark III / Shark Speed Review
reply_split: WOW looks like a very high quality rubber.

thread_title: Haifu Shark III / Shark Speed Review
reply_split: The bubble is a bad sign though, I hope durability it's better than Outlaw's.BTW I have seen this rubber at european retailers but it's very rare among non european retailers.

thread_title: Haifu Shark III / Shark Speed Review
reply_split: I'm glad somebody will finally review this rubber.

thread_title: Haifu Shark III / Shark Speed Review
reply_split: so where stays the review?

thread_title: Haifu Shark III / Shark Speed Review
reply_split: I'm kinda curious about this rubber.

thread_title: Haifu Shark III / Shark Speed Review
reply_split: Good question, I'll ask him  Last time I spoke to him he loved it, the clostest to a real glued up rubber he said... and he's tried a LOT!

thread_title: Haifu Shark III / Shark Speed Review
reply_split: Finally my review is here sorry for the delay but my initial excitment waned.

thread_title: Haifu Shark III / Shark Speed Review
reply_split: As a new season is about to start, I decided to change my old Tenergy 05 both sides which I had been using to coach my students to a softer and faster BH rubber.

thread_title: Haifu Shark III / Shark Speed Review
reply_split: I am a two wing looper who loves massive spin and speed produced from physical power and a grippy but not tacky top sheet.

thread_title: Haifu Shark III / Shark Speed Review
reply_split: As many would agree there are few faults with Tenergy but as I use an all wood 4-ply blade I was wanting a softer sponge to allow more feeling on my BH loop.

thread_title: Haifu Shark III / Shark Speed Review
reply_split: This is very important when having fun while playing against people like Haggisv who with his evil pimples I need all the feeling I can get LOL.

thread_title: Haifu Shark III / Shark Speed Review
reply_split: I have tried many of the latest glue effect rubbers from different companies and always felt none came close to the feeling of how I use to play with a glued up rubber.

thread_title: Haifu Shark III / Shark Speed Review
reply_split: Then Haggisv lent me a new carbon blade and rubber from this French company whom I have never heard of and I really didn't like their rubber.

thread_title: Haifu Shark III / Shark Speed Review
reply_split: It was all speed, little spin or control, but on the BH side was Haifu's Shark 2 tuned and I really liked it!

thread_title: Haifu Shark III / Shark Speed Review
reply_split: It was so light and soft but had amazing power with a grippy Japanese type top sheet.

thread_title: Haifu Shark III / Shark Speed Review
reply_split: I went online shopping and came across Shark 3 and thought hmmm why not go for the top of the line it must be better than 2 because it had a 3 on the packaging LOL.Ok, enough background, lets get to the review.

thread_title: Haifu Shark III / Shark Speed Review
reply_split: Physical properties:Shark 3 is written on the package but on the rubber is Shark Speed, strange to have 2 names for one rubber but it comes in a vacuum packaging the same as Haifu's other tuned rubber like Blue Whale 2 and Shark 2.

thread_title: Haifu Shark III / Shark Speed Review
reply_split: I really was not expecting Shark 3 to be so DIFFERENT from Shark 2.

thread_title: Haifu Shark III / Shark Speed Review
reply_split: When I tested the Shark 2 from Haggisv it used a light super soft yellow sponge but on Shark 3 it has a heavy dense pink sponge.

thread_title: Haifu Shark III / Shark Speed Review
reply_split: I included the pictures of the weights of my uncut Tenergy to compare the uncut Shark 3.

thread_title: Haifu Shark III / Shark Speed Review
reply_split: There is a layer of glue on the back of the pink sponge but it is a lot thinner than the thick layer on my old Blue Whale 2.

thread_title: Haifu Shark III / Shark Speed Review
reply_split: Some people remove this layer to save weight but I think this layer adds to the bounce and feel of the rubber.

thread_title: Haifu Shark III / Shark Speed Review
reply_split: The rubber has quite a good dome straight from the package, while the sponge being an unusual dark pink colour is quite dense and heavy, but is actually quite soft, nothing like any other Chinese rubber I have used.

thread_title: Haifu Shark III / Shark Speed Review
reply_split: Haifu mark this sponge as 34 degrees with their laser type etching on the bottom.This is the first rubber I have ever bought or heard of that has the degrees and thickness hand written on the sponge!

thread_title: Haifu Shark III / Shark Speed Review
reply_split: The factory workers in China must have hand cramps if they mark every sponge personally.

thread_title: Haifu Shark III / Shark Speed Review
reply_split: The sponge has a strong chemical smell but in a nice way, almost fruity.

thread_title: Haifu Shark III / Shark Speed Review
reply_split: The top sheet is where this rubber stands out for me.

thread_title: Haifu Shark III / Shark Speed Review
reply_split: It is so beautiful to look at almost translucent with the Chinese characters looking amazing.

thread_title: Haifu Shark III / Shark Speed Review
reply_split: This sheet is similar to a Japanese Bryce in its looks but feels very Chinese in its texture.

thread_title: Haifu Shark III / Shark Speed Review
reply_split: It is not tacky at all and can not pick up a ball from the table.

thread_title: Haifu Shark III / Shark Speed Review
reply_split: The sheet is extremely grippy just like Tenergy but in a more synthetic way.

thread_title: Haifu Shark III / Shark Speed Review
reply_split: Speed :For the grip this rubber has it has amazing speed Compared to my Tenergy on the same stroke and power it is about 20% faster.

thread_title: Haifu Shark III / Shark Speed Review
reply_split: I would not class it as a speed demon but 20% faster than Tenergy is still quite fast.

thread_title: Haifu Shark III / Shark Speed Review
reply_split: For this amount of speed you get massive spin as well, unlike other speed only rubbers.

thread_title: Haifu Shark III / Shark Speed Review
reply_split: It is more springy than Tenergy but in a wonderful glue feel way.

thread_title: Haifu Shark III / Shark Speed Review
reply_split: I can feel the ball bite into the rubber and it feels like it stays there for a split moment then catapults out like my old speed glue rubbers.

thread_title: Haifu Shark III / Shark Speed Review
reply_split: This feeling I have found missing in all my other glue effect rubbers, so I am thrilled that this Shark3 has this feeling as well as a HUGE click sound.

thread_title: Haifu Shark III / Shark Speed Review
reply_split: It is louder than any rubber I have tried without speed glue and even louder than my Donic F3 Big Slam which only gets its super loud click from a ridiculously super soft sponge.

thread_title: Haifu Shark III / Shark Speed Review
reply_split: Unlike the Big Slam and other soft sponge rubbers which bottom out so easily this Shark3 keeps on spinning and keeping control even with very strong power loops.

thread_title: Haifu Shark III / Shark Speed Review
reply_split: However it does have its limits for a soft sponge so I agree with the recommendation from Haifu that this rubber suits a BH and not a FH if you loop really hard.

thread_title: Haifu Shark III / Shark Speed Review
reply_split: Spin: I see and feel very little difference in the spin generated from Shark 3 compared to my Tenergy.

thread_title: Haifu Shark III / Shark Speed Review
reply_split: Tenergy still has more but the effect on your oponent during the game is very similer.

thread_title: Haifu Shark III / Shark Speed Review
reply_split: On serves it can do all the serves I can do with Tenergy but with far more control.

thread_title: Haifu Shark III / Shark Speed Review
reply_split: Short backspin serves can be done where the ball rolls back to the net after 3 or 4 bounces so plenty of spin.On my BH I can loop backspin more easily than I could with the Tenergy as the ball sinks into the sponge more and gives me more feeling.

thread_title: Haifu Shark III / Shark Speed Review
reply_split: Even though this rubber does have a lower throw than Tenergy it is not a big difference so I did not have to make too many changes to my technique.

thread_title: Haifu Shark III / Shark Speed Review
reply_split: Control :Here again this rubber so surprised me on my punch blocks.The ball just catapults off with a loud crack and goes wherever I wanted it to go.

thread_title: Haifu Shark III / Shark Speed Review
reply_split: I am not fighting with this rubber for control like other speed rubbers but feel it is working with me to put the ball in the right place.

thread_title: Haifu Shark III / Shark Speed Review
reply_split: The same goes for loops.

thread_title: Haifu Shark III / Shark Speed Review
reply_split: I would say it has 70% of the control I get from Tenergy which is really good as I find Tenergy to be one of the best control rubbers out there.

thread_title: Haifu Shark III / Shark Speed Review
reply_split: On pushes this rubber is more springy but still retains it's control.

thread_title: Haifu Shark III / Shark Speed Review
reply_split: I will need to practice more to get my short pushes as short as I could with Tenergy but I think with a few more weeks of practice I will.

thread_title: Haifu Shark III / Shark Speed Review

Your current setup is fast blade + slow but firm rubber.
This isn't a good combination for looping.
The rubbers lack power and the blade + firm sponges require perfect timing, causing the crashes into the net.
Firm sponges need to go with slower, softer blades.
Avoid Tenergy and Tensors.
Setup 1: Avalox BT550 (or similar soft, flexible allround blade, like Dawei Genote A+) + Gambler Wraith or IQUL 42 Deg.
Max sponge.Setup 2: Your current blade + IQUL 40 deg.
You will need to develop your technique to produce your own power.
You will find IQUL / Wraith more powerful than Geospin.
The extra dwell of the softer sponge or slow blade should stop the crashing into the net most of the time and give you enough dwell time to put in your own power.
Either of those setups should get you over 2000 USATT.
I could beat the majority of A Reserve players with either of those setups.I suggest investing money into coaching, at least once a week for a month.
That will make the biggest difference.
I would reccomend that you keep the blade you have and move up to a faster rubber.
The best kind of speed is the speed we generate ourselves because that gives us more control over the game.
IQUL in 40 degrees is a good looping rubber and not crazy fast.
It starts off tacky but then the tackiness wears off and it plays like a Euro rubber.
The 42 degree version is decidedly faster but it may not pair as well with your stiffer blade.
The harder version is however better for the short game, pushing, blocking and is better at handling incoming serves.
The rubber is cheap enough to experiment with which is an advantage.
I think you will not be disappointed.

I say to just save your money and too stick with chinese rubbers.The friendship 729 lightening, higher or the 729-05 are some great rubbers, in order slow to fast with a more jap feel than a traditional one but still with tack like you mentioned.
The outlaw and hurricane neo are much faster maybe 20% more but have less grip or hardly any.

I think i might throw in another side of the story  In order to switch from defensive to offensive gamestyle you need to go too a slower (5 layers without carbon) in order to inprove your skills.The problem with carbon blades is the they are very stiff and hard and therefore they offer very short dwell tim eand thereby control - when you have to change style it is too difficult to learn the strokes if the blade is too slow.
In my opinion it is allways better to have fast rubbers and slower blade than fast blades and slow rubbers.I would think that a all+/off- blade would be a good choice.

I play Butterfly Jonyer Hinoki Special it is about off- it has very nice control and ok ok speed when you need it.I myself have gone from defensive style to offensive and Tenergy 05 opened a new world for me.

If you choose the Tenergy 05 you just have to adapt to the hifgher throw angle and close the angle a little.On the back hand i would try out the Butterfly Roundell which is easy to handle and when you are ready you could then move on to faster bh rubbers.Good luck with the TT journey.
Thanks a lot to all of you for your help.I have taken some classes for a month and it was useful for correcting some of my strokes.
Infact my coach found some problems in my stroke itself.
Have gave me basic coaching.
He told me that Firendship rubbers have one of the hardest sponge which is good for hitting.
I'm still working on three C's Concentration, Control and Confidence.
Moreover reading opponent's spin and weakness is also important in the game.But I still feel I'm lacking some speed on my forehand.
On my carbon blade, I presently have Geospin Tacky 1.9/2 mm.
I'm thinking of buying Geospin Tacky 2.2mm which would give me same rubber with higher speed.
Other options are IQUL 40Deg 2.2mm.
I'm not sure as which one would be the right choice for my forehand.About my backhand, I don't do much looping.

Would IQUL 40Deg 2.2 mm also help me here ?Can Gambler outlaw/Wraith (2.2) FH, IQUL (2.2) would work OK ?I had one more setup which I stopped using after I bought Hinoki carbon.Blade: Aero 896 (medium allrounder)FH:729 CreamBH:RITC 2000 Tack Speed.But again this was more defensive setup that I felt during that time.
Also the overall weight was more and I wanted to move to lighter blade to gain reactive time.Do you think putting fast rubber on this paddle would help ??
How about Gambler outlaw/IQUL 2.2.Thanks.
It takes months and months to improve your strokes.
Lots of hard work.
That's what will make the difference.
Honestly, even the Aero setup should be fast enough to get you over 2000.
You just need the technique to produce the power.
Once again, it's hard work.
It will also test your consistency, short game and tactics, because you won't be able to 'blast' a ball past your opponent in one shot.
Going to a much faster setup is a bit of a short cut.
As for reactive time, develop anticipation and good footwork and the weight won't matter as much.
You seem to want to keep your current carbon blade.
If you want to learn to loop more and be more allround-offensive, use IQUL 40 deg max on both sides.
You could try 42 deg on the forehand of the carbon blade for more power, but I think at your level it will encourage blocking / hitting more than looping.
Avoid outlaw completely and avoid wraith unless you go with a slower, softer blade, like the Aero.IQUL will be noticeably faster than Geospin.
I think at your stage it's unwise to specialise yourself into one style of play, such as 'looper' or 'hitter' etc.
You should learn it all.
Wait until you're closer to 2000, or even over it, before you try to specialise.

well with 2.0s you have greater control compared to 2.2s and thicker sponges.
many prefer 2.2s to generate more power and spin.
As for myself i try to generate more speed and spin through proper technique and 2.0s suit me better.
You also get more feeling with 2.0s
Same, I am of the school of thought that tends to think that you actually lose control if you bottom out and the wood comes into play.
I find that if you develop proper technique, you will find that you are in control of the shot if the sponge does not bottom out.
Once it does, on a harde drive, then the blade is in control of your stroke.
Just my feeling so I tend to go with max, 2.2 or 2.1 if that is available in some cases.

"On the other hand, it is also easier to create spin with tacky rubbers which might make some people lazy, as it is so easy to create spin with them.
"So would you say you would become a better player with Euro/Jap rubbers because it makes you work harder?
You could use the same argument by saying 'tacky rubbers are more sensitive to spin, so it makes you watch the spin more carefully.

Non-tacky rubbers make you lazy as they are less sensitive to spin'Both styles of rubbers have advantages and disadvantages, so neither is better than the other, they are just different and suit different styles.
This is why you still find both types of rubbers even at the Elite levels.
I think this isn't an issue to argue about.
Some people like a bouncy rubber, others like a linear rubber.
I think people buy the stuff they like, whether Japanese/European or Chinese rubber, because it conforms to what they expect the ball to do when they hit it.
Mostly a matter of ball feeling.I would say that you became a better player as a result of forgetting about the equipment and focusing on the other game elements.
If Euro/Jap makes you play like this, then so be it.
Both have their strengths.

Tacky rubbers are great offensive weapons for the short game, serves and massively spinny loops.... however they are not as dynamic as euro type rubbers in that euro rubbers can have a lot of control, I find them easier to loop underspin with, and then with the right blade and sponge hardness they can still produce good mid distance loops.
It depends on where the gears that you need most are at that makes for a good decision to go with one or the other.
True about the top players in the world being chinese, but those players are lucky being able to just play TT in their lives.
I do agree that the subject wasnt something to argue about.
My friend just kept insisting that his chinese equipment was better than my Euro/Jap set up and kept insulting it.
i told him i preferred it but being a good stubborn friend ignored what ive said.
Even though ive finally beaten him w/ my new set up, he still insists the chinese stuff was better.Thanks guys
Fantastic!
Beat him up some more.
But fortunate for me not to have such a friend who seems to be as stubborn as a mule.
Good fortune for you.
i agree speedplay.
My placement has improved greatly after i upgraded FROM chinese rubbers.
Playing w/ euro/jap made me understand what people talked about the "GEARS" of a rubber.
i improved so much, i think i am ready for my first tournament which is going to be in Lakeland,Fl.
A funny thing is that a lot of really good Chinese players use a tacky chinese rubber on their forehand and a Euro/Jap rubber on their backhand.
And many of the professional chinese players who have come to Houston to coach use Butterfly rubbers.
As everyone say, it really depends on your preference.
I have used both Jap rubbers (Sriver, Sriver EL, Tackifire), Euro (Tibhar Intra) and Chinese (729 Fx, 2000-Tack speeds), chinese rubbers are still the ones for me.In terms of quality.
I think Japanese & Euro rubbers are way ahead of chinese rubbers (in terms of rubber life, durability etc.
).However, for a person who's just picking up the sport, I recommend the person to use chinese rubbers because its cheap.
After the person have discovered his playing style, he can then decide to move on to better and more expensive rubbers.
I am totally sold out on the IQUL 2.2 rubbers in 42 degree sponge.
They cost just 16 dollars and at least for me are much better than the more expensive Srivers and Mark Vs.
I also find them to be fast, spinny and great for the short game.
On the other hand this does not mean that Chinese is better than Euro/Jap, just that this particular product is a very good one, as are many other Chinese products.

They are all good, or bad, players have their preferences and for a player who loves Euro equipment, that is the best, etc.I have just tried two Chinese products for the first time, a 5 dollar 729 FX rubber, and from the way it played, I think its an incredible steal at this price.
The other rubber I tried out on a very hard Chinese Real blade is the Blutenkirsche Tokyo rubber.
It seemed very tacky out of the box, but that wore off fast, and now it plays pretty much like a grippy rubber.
Again a decent Chinese product.
The Euro/Jap rubbers usually last longer, usually are uniform with few if any quality control issues.
But if the only factor was playablity, I am sure many Chinese rubbers are as good or better than Euro/Jap rubbers.
Better in fact if the factor was playablity to cost ratio.
I have a new club mate, in St. Joseph's Winter Haven Table Tennis Club, telling me that chinese rubbers are ideal for the younger players because it makes them work more.
I do agree with him, may it be looping underspin, emphasis on spin, or having to rely more on your technique to create speed.
He mentioned that he prefers european rubbers because he is an older gentleman and doesnt have the bone and joints for the dynamics of creating his own speed.
Although chinese equipment do have quality issues, it comes with it with the cheap price tag.
I came up with the conclusion that chinese rubbers tend to make you focus on technique more than euro/jap style rubbers, although we all SHOULD focus on our techniques rather than equipment.
Would you agree w/ my conclusion?Of course a player's preference is a major factor too since it is only my opinion

thread_title: Tenergy 05 Speed comarison beetween 1.9 and 2.1 / max

thread_title: Tenergy 05 Speed comarison beetween 1.9 and 2.1 / max

thread_title: Tenergy 05 Speed comarison beetween 1.9 and 2.1 / max

thread_title: Tenergy 05 Speed comarison beetween 1.9 and 2.1 / max

thread_title: Tenergy 05 Speed comarison beetween 1.9 and 2.1 / max

thread_title: Tenergy 05 Speed comarison beetween 1.9 and 2.1 / max
reply_split: Much depends on the target weight of the paddle and the hitting style of the player.

thread_title: Tenergy 05 Speed comarison beetween 1.9 and 2.1 / max
reply_split: If you were trying to lose grams, or if you were more of a brush looper than a flat-hitter, then the T05 1.9 could be a better choice.

thread_title: Tenergy 05 Speed comarison beetween 1.9 and 2.1 / max

Some people find that change quite acceptable and therefore can make a sheet last for much longer... others need to change it as soon as they notice it, and therefore only get 4-6 weeks out of it.

thread_title: Rubber is dead/not playable - needs a change
reply_split: ask yourself: is it playing any different?

thread_title: Rubber is dead/not playable - needs a change
reply_split: Does it grip the ball as it did on the first weeks/months?You can also ask a regular playing partner who knows quite well of how you play.

thread_title: Rubber is dead/not playable - needs a change
reply_split: Ask him if it was any different compare to before.

thread_title: Rubber is dead/not playable - needs a change
reply_split: That's what we do when trying to decide to get new rubbers/equipment or not.

thread_title: Rubber is dead/not playable - needs a change
reply_split: The physical appearance of the rubber can also be a good indicator of how used up it is.

thread_title: Rubber is dead/not playable - needs a change
reply_split: You can often see a significant difference on the rubber surface, if you compare the area where you usually hit the ball to the edges of the rubber or the part nearer the handle which stays relatively new.

thread_title: Rubber is dead/not playable - needs a change
reply_split: If there is a huge difference there it might be time to change the rubber.But more often then not, the best judge is playability.

thread_title: Rubber is dead/not playable - needs a change
reply_split: Are your serves less spinny, loops have less kick in them, then I guess the rubber is dying, but not dead.At the end of the day it is a personal decision, some players change rubbers when they start to change characteristics, since they want to play with the rubber at its peak performance.

thread_title: Rubber is dead/not playable - needs a change
reply_split: And some extract every last bit of juice from their rubbers, something I would not encourage.

thread_title: Rubber is dead/not playable - needs a change
reply_split: As soon as another rubber takes your fancy.....oops, sorry, that's the EJ answer!!

thread_title: Rubber is dead/not playable - needs a change
reply_split: Seriously though, pay attention to how your rubber feels throughout its life in terms of its grippiness (on your serve, loop, chop, etc), its liveliness, how sweet your shots feel, stuff like that.

thread_title: Rubber is dead/not playable - needs a change
reply_split: When you feel dissatisfied with the rubber's performance, its time to change.

thread_title: Rubber is dead/not playable - needs a change
reply_split: Some people find they don't mind playing with a dead-ish rubber and are happy to continue on with it.

thread_title: Rubber is dead/not playable - needs a change
reply_split: Others find that they are surprised how good a new rubber feels against what their previous rubber had slowly degraded to.

thread_title: Rubber is dead/not playable - needs a change
reply_split: I don't think you can put any hard and fast rules on it though.

Welcome to the forum ScfishrWell, IMO the best thing you can do is to get a blade and rubbers that everybody knows and that allow you to compare with all other kind of rubber/blades (I call this a "Standard"), that allow to "build" your own game, style, and finally blade.OK, One typical Standard would be for example:Blade: Stiga OFFENSIVE or ALLROUNDRubbers: Yasaka Mark V 2.0 mm Red/black or Butterfly SriverIf you say that this combo is too fast, everybody in the world will understand what you mean, even if they have not watched you playing.Another (cheaper, chinese, slower) combo:Blade: LKT InstinctRubber: Friendship 729 (This combo is really easy and cheap to get in e-bay, for example)I'm sure that anyone can suggest you something to begin with.
These are my proposals.Lots of luck with your tests.Q.-

thread_title: Too fast, or just fast enough?

thread_title: Too fast, or just fast enough?
reply_split: It's all about the short game for me, and as Yuzuki pointed out best tested in tense conditions.

thread_title: Too fast, or just fast enough?
reply_split: Am I comfortable touching short, can I dig a little extra on an occasional push, can I push an odd ball right off the bounce to get more spin, can I misdirect a push when I see an opponent move, can I receive serve well?

thread_title: Too fast, or just fast enough?
reply_split: Can I do these things without constantly worrying about going too long.If I can do these things I will certainly be OK in the offensive and blocking games (and strangely also chopping away from the table).If I cannot the better players will destroy me with a superior short game- the foundation of a good player's skills.

thread_title: Too fast, or just fast enough?
reply_split: For me it's all about the short game.

thread_title: Too fast, or just fast enough?
reply_split: If I have trouble pushing or blocking then it is too fast.

thread_title: Too fast, or just fast enough?

thread_title: Hard or soft inverted for chopping?
reply_split: I suspect at the higher levels, they MUST be able to generate heavy backspin on their chops, and if a rubber bottoms out this will be harder to do.If you want to counter loop, then a really soft and thin sponge is hopeless as well, as it bottoms out even on medium pace loops.

thread_title: Hard or soft inverted for chopping?
reply_split: A 1.2mm sponge is very thin... we do have a few player that play with 1.8mm soft sponge, and are still able to loop quite effectively unless it's hit really hard...I think with a non-tacly rubber, it would be much easier to generate heavy backspin in the short game.

thread_title: Hard or soft inverted for chopping?
reply_split: For a hard sponged rubbers you'd need a tacky surface to do this so that you can brush it finely, where the hard sponge does not reduce the dwell time as well...These are the main contribting factors I can think off... Hopefully some of our inverted choppers can add some more comments?

thread_title: Hard or soft inverted for chopping?
reply_split: No matter how much backspin it has, if you place it not deep enough, or doesn't have enough speed, your opponent still can smash the ball.

thread_title: Hard or soft inverted for chopping?

thread_title: Hard or soft inverted for chopping?

reply_split: And, a BIG plus is you dont have to chop far far away from the table, so less running around.

I always thought stiga almana played similar, just tad slower.
Perhaps boost TP might be a cheaper alternative.
Bryce Speed is actually an excellent rubber.
Bryce is the one I have a problem with.

Bryce Speed has a much grippier topsheet, and better speed, whilst maintaining similar control properties.The thing with BS that I found to be really unique is that it was horrible to kill backspin with, the margin of error was so low, and the shot produced was less than exceptional.

However, I could counter loop off the bounce with it very easily and the ball is much, much, much faster than even tuned Chinese stuff.To the point now: because of this uniqueness, I've never found anything that could truly mimic BS.
The ones that come close are all in the Butterfly range.

I'll see if there's any windfall of cash in the near future then, as I really liked the properties of tuned/glued Bryce, and can't really control Tenergy 25 on the backhand well enough for it to be game-worthy.

It has a lot of potential, however.As for Almana, I just hope this incoming Sterco (two sheets) would be enough to tide me over while waiting for Bryce Speed.Thanks for the rather quick replies, you two.
The Almana is quite similar to Sterco in many ways...
Yeah, that's why I asked for a couple from you.
I'm hoping that Sterco is merely a spinnier, slower version of Bryce Speed (a spinnier Almana if you will) with a sponge which doesn't require tuning.
I've tried it before on the forehand, a long time ago, so I'm not sure about it's properties now with my current skill set.Interesting that views change as people change.
I'm amazed at the ability of Tenergy 25 for the backhand, but with my current self, I can't work it out well enough.
Try Dawei Saviga, it's cheap so trying one won't kill you
Yes, I've seen the Saviga too.It's meant to be a Butterfly Bryce clone, and all of the reviews about it are positive as well.Worth a try, because it's fairly cheap.
IMO it only comes close to bryce in the hard sponged version, and when it's glued up...
Ive tried Saviga,Inspirit and Inspirit Quattro and they are not in the same league as Bryce.
I would Suggest Platin on the bh side.I have tried many bh rubbers but this one i brilliant in serve return hitting looping.I have Tenergy 05 on the fh and this is a perfect combo..

I agree actually, from my experience of talking to sponsored players, apparently the combo shown on the Donic site: some blade + JO Gold (FH) + Platin (BH) is the best thing since the glue ban (for Donic users), so +1 for the Platin idea.

Thanks to both, as Platin is as expensive as Silver here locally, I'll give it a shot if I decide to buy Donic.But my first and lasting impression of Platin is it's like a Sriver EL Tensor, so I'm not particularly inclined in that route.I find JO Gold a bit too low throw and a bit too hard for my backhand, needing much armspeed, but certainly has a faster ball.

all right does everyone see it this way ?Or is it just yuzuki  I would really want to know everybody`s oppinion regarding this..
If you are an intermediate player or better, I advocate using the maximum thickness on both sides.
If this is impossible to control, use a slower blade or slower sponge.
Platin is very fast.
I find the 1,8 Platin easy to control.I just wonder how different the max rubber will be.I was told that the max thickness needs firm/hard strokes and by now I hit the ball pretty hard.

But how much control do you sacrifice when going from 1,8 to max ?And is it much tougher to hit with the max or is it not much different ?I use the TBS which is fast but have nice feel and control for a carbon blade..
It will take you a couple of weeks to get used to it, probably, and then you will like it better.
Here's the rub: Some rubbers have maximum thicknesses of more than 2.1-2,2mm like some European rubbers.

Others, like Tenergy and Bryce, have it maxed out at 2.1mm.It's a little iffy for me to say this, but I 'play drill OK' with 2.1mm Tenergy 25 on the backhand, which is the maximum thickness of the particular rubber.So, I guess I am playing max on the backhand?
I will test the Platin max one of the coming days And will then see how big the difference will be.I will let you know how it feels.

As promised here are my initial impressions of the Platin in max.I found it a little difficult to to passive pushes, they seemed to pop up a little.
I will have to practice this a little more and maybe push a bit harder to control it.Blocking with the Platin max is just amazing, I have never before returned that many loops.
Usually when playing a heavy spin looper i tend to block it long and high, with the max bh I had almost no trouble with it.

It seemed like the max rubber react quite a bit less to spin  Also from the middle distance i found it very easy to control the opponents loops.What a power I have from my bh side  I almost get afraid when i hammer it past the opponent  of course I had a few hits off the table but that was expected.I won against all the players that I usually does so I did`nt really perform worse than normal, I was expecting a heavy fall in service return quality.I feel that it is more neccesary to go "over" the ball because it is quite hard so when looping too direct causes it to sink into the net.I think that my service returns is about the same quality as with the 1,8 but off course the rubber feels different and it feels a bit harder, maybe that is because of the thick sponge ?I feel that with this equipment I can make my journey towards the next goal: to become a class 2 player.I may need to explain the tournament classes in Denmark:Class 5: beginnersClass4 : Below Average.Class 3 : Intermidiate players.
This is where I am located now.Class 2: Above average players.Class 1: Very Good players these players plays in the division leagues.Elite: Do I have to explain this class

Sorry about splitting of my post, this forum has issues about long posts  I feel that in the longterm this setup will make me a far better player.I feel even when the opponent has the initiative I can hold him away from blasting it past me.I can block almost anything.

My bh loops when on the table they are lethal they are both fast and carries a lot of side spin.I feel that I Can develop much more pressure on the opponent even without hitting it hars since that setup bh rubber is fast and hard but still spinny and easyli controlled.I will have my 2nd session on Saturday hope that it will improve even more....
No, no issues about long posts!

Firstly your post is a bit vague it is hard for me or anyone else to give you a solid response.
This is because we do not know how good your FH loop is, or if you prefer hard rubbers or soft rubbers?
We need to know abit more info about how your looping style is and what type of characteristics you are looking for.
For example, i have used G2-fx on my BH i hated it, i found it too soft, therefore i tryed to use it on my FH.
My looping abilty is pretty dam good but i still stuggled with the rubber because i found it tooo soft.
Its a great rubber to block with and you do get a nice feel/control with it.
I found it great for serves also.
As a result i found out that i prefer harder rubbers.
I have played with bryce and i liked it.
The hardness allowed me to get more power into my loops aswell as the spin.
This is IMO.

Hence without knowing how your game is i would not like to suggest a rubber for you to purchase - just in case it comes out to become a terrible set up and you hate me for it   Ps: Once edited i will give more info...
It looks like I'm getting mixed responses, which isn't a good thing for me  .To Ilovetabletennis and others, I knew I should of given more info, but due to laziness to type I left it out.
Anyway, my FH loop is pretty good.
I have been coached by a Chinese Provincial Team player and she has taught be the Chinese looping game, which consequently means looping with legs + waist + extended arm.

I can put loop close and away from table.I have used Six Shooters and Outlaw for my FH before, and I quite liked Six Shooters on my FH for looping even though Six Shooters is supposedly a better rubber for a backhand-blocking style of game (I love from both wings anyhow).
I have not bought tried many rubbers (only tried around four).
So, is hard for me to say what hardness of rubber I would like frpm this small sample.
However, I would like a rubber that has almost the same feel as Six Shooters, which I think might be medium-soft?

I have used the Outlaw for a month now and even though I can loop with it with no problem, I don't like its feel, which could be medium-hard or hard?Furthermore, if this helps according to my coach I could be easily rated 1800+ but because tournaments are held on Sundays at my club, I can't play them (I have to work  ).
I have beaten players that are 1800+ too.
Have you tried G2FX?
Yes it's soft, but I don't find it grippier or spinnier than Bryce.
Bryce is a respectable rubber without glue.
If speedglue had never been invented, G2FX wouldn't have either (IMO Sriver L is better for pretty much anything).
I dare anyone to say something good about G2FX that doesn't involve speedglue/tuners:)
Ok so here is my little comparison, I hope it helps.
Thanks again for giving me a bit more info it will help me with my advice.G2fx - A low throw, soft, light rubber that's not super fast, nor powerful compared to bryce and other tensor rubbers.
I must admit even if i dislike this rubber it is very good in every catorgory.
Very well balanced, It most proberly plays better on a faster blade, as it will allow you to gear up more easily.
Also the durablity of this rubber is long lasting.
Hence a good rubber for intermidiate players who cannot handle upgraded rubbers such as Tenergy.
This rubber performs MUCH better with speed glued or if it is tuned.
When serving with this rubber i can really get some nice spinny serves which kick off the table or kick off peoples bat.
Bryce- This is an excellent rubber, low throw rubber for pure offense, It's one of the best blocking rubbers I used and its also great for driving and smashing.
In the short game is a little bit more difficult to control, but this is when practice comes in handy!
Very good for power looping.
Comparing it to G2FX it has LESS spin.

But has MUCH more speed (if that makes sense ) When i served with this rubber i also found it spinny, it also gave me nice control over the shot.On the other hand...If you like six shooters why do you want to change rubbers?
Wouldn't it be easier and more effiecent to buy a rubber you played with an enjoy playing with?
Is it becasue you feel like you are gettign a really good offer on the two rubbers?
( I smell a ongoing EJ  )If you really want to buy the rubber why dont you purchase them if they are cheap, and then sell them on with a bit more $$$ on top (make a profit)?
Then you could buy a few more Six Shooters!
I cannot say much about Outlaw as i have not used it (i would have but i got Tenergy).

Thanks.For some reason, I have the impression that the G2-FX is more of a smashing-kind-of-rubber than a looping rubber.And, I'm not buying another Six Shooter rubber even though I like it because the quality is bad.
After a month of playing with the rubber the edges had fallen apart to the point that I have to change rubbers.
Then, I bought the Outlaw and in less than a week there are already cracks at the edges of the rubber.
I mean Gambler might make good-playing rubbers, but gosh the quality is horrible.
By the way, I don't hit the edges of the table.Furthermore, I'm changing rubbers because my coach and other players better than me say that I need to upgrade rubbers since I have gotten better.
I feel the same way too.
They all recommended me Tenergy 25 and they say it suits my style.
However the rubber cost $60, and I don't feel like paying that much yet.
I'm getting the Bryce and G2FX for only $20 each, so I decided to give them a try.
Fair Enough.
I think if you will be speed gluing/ tuning buy the G2fx OR if your going to play standardly buy the bryce.
Unless you seek to play with a slower rubber.
So, I decided to buy both rubbers today since they were cheap  .
Tried the Bryce first and I didn't like it.
The rubber was too hard for my taste.
No feeling at all.
Then tried the G2-FX, and I liked this one.
Same feeling as my Six Shooters but a little bit faster.
No need for speed gluing (never done it before) to get speed, since I use my full arm/stroke and get enough speed with it.
I'm quite happy with the G2-FX, a soft rubber which is what I like.
I am glad you took both of them, One of the first questions i asked was, do you like soft or hard rubbers, you wasn't able to answer it since you didnt know.
I asked this first because this was one of the key differences.
If you was able to give me a accurate response i could have told you which one you prefer.
But atleast now you know what your style is like, sell on the bryce  if i was near you i would have purchased it.I hope the rubber plays well for you.

thread_title: FH rubber for close/mid-distance chopping and attack?
reply_split: The issue with a rubber for chopping is that it doesn't want to be too fast or bouncy otherwise the ball is gone before you get much chance to inflict any great degree of spin on it.

thread_title: FH rubber for close/mid-distance chopping and attack?
reply_split: This means that a thicker sponge will eject the ball out quicker and be worse for chopping.

thread_title: FH rubber for close/mid-distance chopping and attack?
reply_split: Obviously the more grip you get from the topsheet the better, whereas with a looping rubber it can come from the sponge or the topsheet because you can apply more force to the ball as you are giving the ball downward force.

thread_title: FH rubber for close/mid-distance chopping and attack?
reply_split: It is more delicate chopping because you give upward force generally, so you can't rely much on the sponge to provide this, it has to come from the topsheet.

thread_title: FH rubber for close/mid-distance chopping and attack?
reply_split: A chopped ball will float in the air and go further, whereas a topspin ball will be dragged down by the spin force.

thread_title: FH rubber for close/mid-distance chopping and attack?
reply_split: So in seeking a chopping rubber you need to look for a very grippy or tacky topsheet with a thinner or deader sponge.

thread_title: FH rubber for close/mid-distance chopping and attack?
reply_split: Alternatively you can join us on the darkside and use long pimples which vary in the amount of chop spin they create themselves, but take the topspin of the opponent and send it back as underspin when using a chopping action.

thread_title: FH rubber for close/mid-distance chopping and attack?
reply_split: Anti-spin rubbers will do something similar, though I don't use it, so can't be very detailed on its effects.

thread_title: Is Andro Roxon 450 for me??//first impressions

thread_title: Is Andro Roxon 450 for me??//first impressions
reply_split: so not flustered by my performance, I took on the #2, and the warmup was fun, he was a lefty but that didnt matter, playing the rallies were so much fun, and i could hear that "ping" you get with speed glue and SGE, I wouldnt say the fact he also had a SGE helped, or the speed helped, but I started to get the timing right, and when i was blocking, man, it can block.

thread_title: Is Andro Roxon 450 for me??//first impressions
reply_split: my worst part was a couple times I lost points which after I lost them i said to myself "hey, dont loop it, with you cant do that shot with this rubber, block it".

thread_title: Is Andro Roxon 450 for me??//first impressions
reply_split: I didnt win any games, we must of played 5-6 games, i lost them and got between 6-8 points each game, im not used to playing chops that heavy that short, if tried to lift them over with the pips and struggled getting a good possition, and i got them over with the roxom but was bad placements

thread_title: Is Andro Roxon 450 for me??//first impressions
reply_split: im looking foward to tomorrow and friday night, see if i can keep it up.

Chop off the table?
Block close?
Loop?
I have used the 1.7 only.
I did like it but, if you are going to chop off the table don't think you will be able to get into a loop counter loop with someone.
You can't.
Not nearly fast enough.
Don't get me wrong.
It will put away a loose ball but you won't be hitting it past someone with a powerloop.
So figure out what you want and go from there.
Good luck.

Thanx, other opinions ?
I've used Hammond and Optimum MP (it was a while ago so forgive me if I'm a bit vague) and Hammond definitely has a softer feel and is slightly faster.
I found Hammond a much more controllable and predictable looping rubber, although both are capable of generating a lot of spin on loops.
OMP has a much grippier topsheet and is better for serving but neither is great.
Hammond is less susceptible to incoming spin and easier to return serve with.
Both are fairly good for blocking and poor for pushing.
Which Hammond is it that you're using?
I used to use the Pro Alpha and thought it was pretty good.
I tried all the Hammond rubbers and I thought the Pro A was the best.
I got more spin and with the right blade, it is as fast as anybody needs.
This was for an attacking, countering type game.
I could still switch back to it today with no problem.
I also found it to be a very durable rubber.
Hmmm, maybe as I look to upgrade the speed on my forehand I should consider returning to the Hammond Pro Alpha.
Now, I'll have to dig through my cache of equipment to see if I have a spare sitting around from a few years ago...
I had the Hammond X on a killerspin blade and loved it.
I was a little fast for me, and not spinny enough to setup a proper kill shot.
Thanks for all the great info.
I keep hearing that OMP has a hard sponge and that producing spin can sometimes be a problem.
Can the same be said for Mendo MP?
I would sacrifice some speed to get a little more spin with reg MP.
Also does Yasaka V Stage have the same hard sponge and lesser grip tendencies as well?
Also that HPA is as good or better than reg Hammond.
I think it may produce a little more spin but is somewhat slower than reg Hammond.
Hammond X may be somehwere in between?
Thanks again!
If it was just a comparision between the three, Hammond is the angry older brother, Hammond pro A is the sensitive type, and Hammond X is the career orientated sucessful sun.
Hammond X is neither the fastest or spinniest, but is faster then the A but spinnier then the Hammond.

thread_title: which is better for flicks (bh)? tenergy 1.9 or 2.1?
reply_split: Deb, I haven't used Tenergy but I'd say the principals are the same.

thread_title: which is better for flicks (bh)? tenergy 1.9 or 2.1?
reply_split: I think generally a thinner sponge would be better for a flick for the extra control you get and the less catapulting that occurs to send the ball off beyond where you intended.

thread_title: which is better for flicks (bh)? tenergy 1.9 or 2.1?
reply_split: However, I would say the more important thing is having the correct technique and blade angle for the shot and for the rubber and sponge you are using.

thread_title: which is better for flicks (bh)? tenergy 1.9 or 2.1?
reply_split: So overall, I think sponge thickness is not as important as getting the shot right.

thread_title: which is better for flicks (bh)? tenergy 1.9 or 2.1?
reply_split: I would recommend 1.9 in some other rubber.

thread_title: which is better for flicks (bh)? tenergy 1.9 or 2.1?
reply_split: The Tenergy is Very Hard and does not work well with very hard stiff blades.

thread_title: which is better for flicks (bh)? tenergy 1.9 or 2.1?
reply_split: I myself use Platin on my Bh because the Tenergy is to hard and 2 sheets of Tenergy will be too heavy.

thread_title: which is better for flicks (bh)? tenergy 1.9 or 2.1?
reply_split: Yes I think the sponge does not matter so much for the flick, as it's a low impact shot...so I'd choose 1.9mm for better control.

thread_title: which is better for flicks (bh)? tenergy 1.9 or 2.1?
reply_split: Because this shot has no backswing or other telltale, when I execute it properly -- particularly on a short ball or unsuspecting serve -- it's usually behind my opponent before they have a chance to even begin moving their paddle.

thread_title: which is better for flicks (bh)? tenergy 1.9 or 2.1?
reply_split: I recently bought Tihbar Nimbus Soft for a med fast 9-ply homemade blade that I use.

thread_title: which is better for flicks (bh)? tenergy 1.9 or 2.1?
reply_split: Paddle Palace convinced me that I didn't want max sponge for my BH so I got the second thickest for BH (in black) and max on the FH (in red).

thread_title: which is better for flicks (bh)? tenergy 1.9 or 2.1?
reply_split: It turns out that there was a noticeable difference in how those two sheets played, particularly on my BH flick/loop.

thread_title: which is better for flicks (bh)? tenergy 1.9 or 2.1?
reply_split: The thinner sponge bottomed out easily and often went long.

thread_title: which is better for flicks (bh)? tenergy 1.9 or 2.1?
reply_split: The max sponge never bottomed out and would take far shorter paths to the table.

thread_title: which is better for flicks (bh)? tenergy 1.9 or 2.1?
reply_split: I was surprised that so little difference in sponge thickness could make such a difference.

thread_title: which is better for flicks (bh)? tenergy 1.9 or 2.1?
reply_split: If you brush loop your flick shots as I sometimes do then sponge thickness isn't nearly as critical (then it's all about keeping your topsheet clean).

thread_title: which is better for flicks (bh)? tenergy 1.9 or 2.1?
reply_split: But if you drive into the ball I think you'll want all the thick, soft sponge you can get.

thread_title: which is better for flicks (bh)? tenergy 1.9 or 2.1?
reply_split: UPDATE: I've since had the chance to hit some more with Tenergy 2.1 and find its dense, springy sponge (which is nothing like Nimbus) virtually impossible to fully compress.. but also (on the right blade) very compelling!

thread_title: which is better for flicks (bh)? tenergy 1.9 or 2.1?
reply_split: I'm ordering my own sheet soon.. in 1.9 for my bh.
I have not tried that rubber so I can't comment...
But I can suggest that the soft sponged Tensors tend to have the greatest speed-glue click...
Spin with slow strokes(serv - push): tenergy> boost series> tensors
Spin with fast strokes (loop) tenergy> boost series = tensors
Speed: tenergy> tensors > boost series
click sound: tensors> boost series > tenergy
Boost Series rubbers are very similar to tensors.
But they are not that springy-tensioned as tensors.
Serving and pushing is a bit better.
Blocking is safer.
But boost tp & tc are flat trajectory rubbers so they are not good for backhand.
But they are decent rubbers for forehand.
If you think tenergy is too heavy and too expensive than you can go with the boost series...
Nice summary Tsu.
One thing to add; Boost rubbers are more durable than Tensors.
yes I hear they are VERY soft rubbers.
What exactly are the strengths if this rubber?
Thkz
It makes no sense to generalize about tensors.
They come in a very wide range.
For example, F3 Big Slam and Jo Gold could not possibly be more different.
Even JO Gold and JO Silver play differently and tend to suit different kinds of players.
Moreover, the playing characteristics of any rubber depend a lot on what blade you use it on.
And of course whether or not it is "better" for you depends on how you play (and often how well).
So a rating system on any one things that says something like Tenergy > Boost > tensors is pretty questionable.
It is like comparing Cherrys to oranges to vertebrates.
Even as to the question of durability, there is quite a bit of difference among tensors.
Baal, couldn't agree more.I second and triple your opinion
yes I hear they are VERY soft rubbers.
What exactly are the strengths if this rubber?
Thkz
Sorry, can't help, nobody at my club has tried it.
TP has a medium sponge (Sriver EL maybe Magna) while TC has a soft sponge (something like Coppa Silver).
I may generalize that Boost series are more durable than tensors (used many tensors including some latest gen.).
Boost series are less bouncy.
TP has nice topsheet grip whereas TC is an absolute mechanical spin rubber.
Many tensors have better topsheet grip.
Both are low throw (TP was lower as far as I remember).
Both are light, TC being very light.

I have used Hammond Alpha and Hammond X.
Both are pretty fast.
When it comes to how spinny they are, I think it has to do with playing style to a degree.
Neither one will compete with a sticky rubber on brush loops but when driving, both are very spinny to me as evidenced by the blade angle required to block loop drives by them.
People judge spin some by the arc given when looping but,,,if you were to fire a fast bullet and a slow bullet parrallel to the ground, both would hit at the same time.
The fast bullet traveled further though so the arc is flatter.
I think the same applies to rubber spin.
The fastest rubbers have a flatter trajectory even though they may have put just as much spin on the ball as a slower rubber.
I also think that is why Hammond type rubbers block so well, they need a hard hit to "get a hold" on the ball and ignore some of the spin when blocking.
Speed glueing obviously can change this but I don't speed glue.
platin is faster and spinnier than hammond x unglued.
heavily glued hammond X is much faster and spinnier than platin.

Hmm, I could have swore I've compared Sriver EL vs. JO Platin...
I guess the only input I could give is that JO Platin is good for loop driving, and somewhat average for brush looping.
I agree that spin can't be completely judged by the arc of the ball, however the part about the bullet doesn't translate to table tennis.
Bullets have screwball spin so they basically travel straight independent of spin and speed.
Looped table tennis balls travel with topspin, and the flight of the ball varies depending on both the spin and the speed.
The faster the ball, the more downward force is applied by the air above the spinning ball.
If i recall correctly it's a velocity-squared relation so a 60mph loop experiences four times as much downforce as a 30mph loop.
The faster loop will hit the ground before the slower loop.
Though ideally you'd want the loop to hit the table, not the ground, and determining whether it's advantageous to hit harder to get more arc is much too complicated to figure in any given situation.
Instincts and your practice partner's observations work a lot better.
I was hitting with someone who was using some tensor stuff, and they were really consistent looping with it in practice (personally i think the control on the stuff is awful).
Unfortunately their loops had nice arc and hit the table not because of great spin or control, but rather because the loops were all really really slow.
Sounds like from what I have read that there is not really a significant difference between Hammond/ Hammond X/ J.O.
Platinum/ Optimum MP.
I think if I had to choose right now it would be betwen the Platinum and the Optimum MP.
I already have a setup with the Hammond on it and I do not feel that the Hammond X is that much different.
Right now I feel that even though the Platinum may be somewhat spinnier that the Opt.
MP is not far behind and it is as fast if not a little faster.
I also loved the durability of regular MP topsheet and the feel it gave me.
Reg MP was pretty fast for me so the nano sponge for Opt.
MP must make it a real rocket!!
Thanks again for all your great advice!
I agree there is more downforce on a faster ball but you are leaving out the increased momentum of the ball.
If what you say is correct, a ball looped hard would have a sharper arc than a slow ball.
I think there are to many factors for us to solve it here.
I know if you put a rubber on a slow blade and loop one, it has a sharper arc than if you put it on a fast blade.
I doubt if the amount of spin is much different while the arc is very different.
The bullet anolagy was the only one I could think of to try and give an idea about how spin/speed relate.
The blade angle required to block a loop tells alot about how much spin is on a ball.
Like it was mentioned, another person receiving the ball will have a good idea how much spin was really on the ball.
Yes a faster ball has higher momentum, but the momentum is horizontal so it's irrelevant when looking at how quickly the ball will drop.
Given two balls with equal rpms and different speeds, the faster ball definitely has a sharper arc, as the force of air resulting from spin is more than gravity.
(Whether the sharper arc is enough to overcome the fact that it spends less time over the table is unknown.)
Yeah, the person receiving the ball ought to have a good idea of how much spin is really on the ball.
However that person also needs to understand how their racket reacts to spin.
A more closed racket does not mean the ball has more spin and speed; a lot of times a faster ball with equal spin requires a more open racket.
Yes intuitively I'd say you're right, but it's hard to prove since we have no way of imparting equal spin at different speeds.
I also think faster loops often carry less spin, as you tend to put more energy into speed instead of spinning the ball... a lot of exceptions to this of course...
I've used Hammond, Hammond X and Optimum MP, all not speed glued.
They are all fast rubbers.
For spin
Hammond X > OMP > Hammond
For speed probably
Hammond > OMP > Hammond X
The main difference I found in use was that OMP [b]felt[/b] much harder than the Hammonds and I ended up stopping using it for that reason.
I do not know Hammond or Hammond X - but I can tell that regular Platin os much faster that both JO silver and gold.
I use it on my FH and cant believe the speed i get.
I wonder if anyone have any experience with it in the soft version.
Speedy

I am useing it to find out if there is any damage to the sheet in time.
Two weeks so far.
Interesting, as far as I know the 36-38deg is the softest available... are you sure it's 35deg, or is it a different sponge?
I use spinmax, so keeping it tacky won't be an issue.

I have not tried many euro rubbers glued up, and the venus tuned with Falco booster is certainly faster than any unglued rubber when you start looping.. the tack slows it down in the slower parts of the game...
Whoooopppppssssss, 38 degree
Would this be a good rubber for both hitting and looping and punchblocking?
It was excellent for both looping and hitting, but remember it was glued up with Falco booster so it won't quite behave the same way without...
I don't really punch block so I can't comment, but for normal blocking it worked very well and was surprisingly insensitive to spin considering it's a tacky rubber....
don't worry I have my lamp oil ready!
As a replacement for Energy, Venus is great.
I went through alot of other stuff trying to find a less expensive rubber.
At $14 Venus is my setup.
It does everything my Energy did.
It is ordered, if I can, I try it as soon as I receive it.

Hi Hookshot...I have LKT Pro XT which is a tacky rubber as the name says..(XT = extra tacky) and that has remained tackier than it was new for 3 - 4 months now with Spinmax, and an occasional treatment of Eucalyptus Oil and a stint in the sun or under a light for 2 hours brings up that glossy tack that I cannot live without...lol....

Its quite dramatic what the EO does and the rubbers just slurp it up...apart from helping maintain tackiness, this EO treatment causes the topsheet to become tuned...Ie the increased size makes the topsheet more dense and adds speed..

Anyway, it might not be a bad idea to get some Spinmax Aqueous from Alex...it would be there before you know it, and also try the EO in the sunlight if your sun is warm, or 100 watt light globe at about 12 inches ...watch the heat.
I gave a sheet of Mercury (Venus's sister rubber with a Chinese sponge) to a friend a few weeks ago, and he has maintained the rubber tackier than it was at new using the above treatment regime...
I do realise I sound a bit like a broken record going on about Spinmax and EO,  but the fact is that they work!!
!so please forgive my enthusiasm about the products...
fosss
Thanks for the review Alex!
I've been looking forward to hearing your thoughts on this rubber, as I've been looking to try it out for some time now.
By the way, I was able to try out some 999 national on a cayman the other day; you weren't kidding about the spin on that sheet!
It felt great for looping--tons on speed and spin--but I couldn't chop worth a damn with it...
Foss, do you apply EO to the sponge and the rubber or just the topsheet?
Do you find it increases the overall dimensions of your sheet, and the shrinks back, but not to original size?
If so do you trim it, or does this only happen the first time?
Yep that's pretty much spot on!
I was able to do a couple of hits with a Venus 2.2 mm and felt great ; very euro-like .
I liked the low-throw and the "kick".

ok, i have used this venus 2.2mm black sheet for the last 4-5times and after using it as is out of the package, i decided to see what it was like super priming it and giving it some spinmax, it was a monster!
i love the extra gears in it and the kick is amazing.
the low throw sure frustrates people i play with!
anyway, it sure is a good piece of rubber that does everything exceptionally good and cheap!
i have found a replacement for some of my euro/jap rubbers.
i think that boosting it is the go since speed glue will be banned...

overall, it will be something that i will stick with for a little while as my forehand is now more consistant and has more variation with transition from flat to spin/kicks with a matter of rotating my wrist.
im beginning to love this new sheet!
i was wondering it the red sheet has the same tack?
That's good to hear!
I doubt the red will be as tacky.
BTW How does the low throw frustrate people you play with?
basically the low throw makes them think that it doesnt spin much or that it is more of a flatter hitting shot rather than a spinning ball.
also that when my stroke seems like a heap of spin has gone into it and the ball does not rise much they tend to mishit or misblock...
my hitting partner was telling me that he tends to step back a bit getting ready to counter and yet the ball has dipped before he gets to counter it.
Low throw rubbers also tend to cause the topspin kick after the bounce to act differently.
Hmmm intersting...
I've certainly seen balls kick differently from different rubbers, but I've never try to relate it to throw...
Not already tried it but are you still happy with the Venus?
I think my Era is a bit slow without speed glue and a bit to hard but as I win a lot of matchs, I really hesitate to change it.
Yes I have not changed my mind on it.
I do find that in 2.0mm it bottoms out a little, only in fast counterloops away from the table...of course the fact that it's only 2.0mm has a lot to do with this...

Compared to the 999 Nat, the venus is much more controllable, except the 999 Nat gets a bit more spin, it's a little easier to do real slow spinny loops (as the 999 topsheet is softer) and and it never bottoms out...
Trying venus in 2.2mm again is another option for me...

Hi Krypto,
When I first discovered this forum and shop I ran across a review of both those rubbers.
I think it was on the shop review site, so I suggest having a look there.
From memory the Skyline was considered a nicer looking rubber, but the advantage of it ended there.
I seem to remember the reviewer (who may have been LAWOCG saying that Skyline was hard work to get looping compared to H3.
But don't trust my memory, go search for it.
Cheers,
Reb.
Yeah, I already know LawOCG´s review but he tested Skyline 3
with some layers of Speedglue, which makes the rubber very different
from the unglued version.
But I still told me somethign about the quality.
I am still not sure if its a waste of money for me or if I shall try it.
I've never actually tried the skyline 3, but I don't belive it's that lively.
I have tried skyline 2 in 1.5mm, which is fantastic for hitting/blocking pushing style game...not sure id that help....
The LKT Pro Xt is quite a bit slower, and much softer sponged rubber...
It can generate a lot of spin with little arm movement... i really liked this one, but in the end I found it too slow on my blade (energy wood) which is already not that fast...
Hmm, ok thanks, I think I will come back to
my good old Hurricane 3 2,2mm and stop testing
for a while
XP is very very soft.
It's very very slow when unglued but has amazing sound and spin when glued with respectable speed.
For chopping, though, it's not great.
I chopped for a few months with XP on the forehand and found it difficult to create anything other than float or weak backspin.
My counterloops, though, were ridiculous.
If you're on the very offensive end of the "modern defense scale" then XP could work, but otherwise stick to the hard, tacky rubbers like the Hurricane series
Hmm if its slow AND doesn´t chop well its not what I search for.
I want a really fast rubber with which you can still chop.
Spin is very important for me!
For example: I played Globe 999 nat (black) on a De-1 (i would rate it Off-)
glued with 4 layers on VH fo some days.
The Speed and control was great and I could vary the spin in defense very well but I couldn´t do heavy chops with MUCH underspin.
I ordered a Hurricane 3 and Kokutaku 868 40-43° (both 2.2mm)
now cause I think they´re the best choice for me.
I really think the Hurricane will make it.
If someone knows more about Skyline and thinks it could be the right rubber for me, please tell me

Thanks for the advice, I was thinking Hammond X might be a good option.
You're right, if I prefer less bouncy rubbers, tensors are probably not the way to go.
I tried F1 once and won't again.
I've used 802-40 before and it's a good rubber but I prefer a bit more spin to contrast with my short pips forehand.
I'm not sure about the weight of Nodias, but you could just try either Cermet or Sriver.
Cermet felt pretty light to me.
Also, although it's really fast and fairly bouncy, I loved using a thinner sheet of Juic Varites on RPB (I used 1.8, but I think even 1.5 would be fast enough).
It's featherlight and can generate pretty good spin.
Sriver is nothing special compared to Nodias
In terms of weight or performance?
When I've hit with regular Sriver it felt fine, but the sheets were pretty old and I didn't really test it.
I still like Nodias, just not the weight as the blade I'm using now is 10 grams heavier than my old one.
Mambo C is okay weight-wise but slippery and a little low throw unglued.
I may try Donic J.O.
Waldner in 1.8 but that probably won't save all that much in weight.
both.
Of course Sriver is fine but it doesn't do anything better than nodias.
cermet is quite light.
How does Varites compare to Hammond-X or Bryce-FX in terms of bounce, spin and throw?
I've been using TSP Brio for RPB, which has good speed, but I'd like something with more spin.
Sriver series is a good choice too, however I want to avoid gluing.

In the same sponge thickness, Varites beats regular Bryce in speed, both glued and unglued, but I think it has better gears than Bryce too, since I would always pop up pushes with Bryce, but they're still fairly easy to keep low with Varites.

Because the sponge is a bit harder than Bryce and the topsheet is a bit softer, you're going to have to make a slightly different motion to generate spin, but it's just about the same in spin overall, perhaps just slightly better.
Throw is medium, so you might need some adjusting to keep your shots on the table at first.
In general, I don't think you should use it on a hard blade; it feels a bit too unstable on those.
If you pair it with a medium or soft blade, it's really great.
Edit: Oh, you said Bryce FX.
Well it's definitely faster than the FX version, but its spin isn't as high when unglued.

Because the sponge on Varites loosens up a ton when you glue it (although you can use boosters as well, since I see you don't want to glue), I'd say glued (or equivalent) Varites is pretty close to unglued Bryce FX, but with the same treatment, Bryce FX is going to win for spin.
Hobbes (or anyone) what is the difference in effect from speed glue to boosters.
Do boosters still wear the rubber out quicker?
Are they applied to the sponge or topsheet?
Cermet is pretty light.
Hammond X is very light.
Perhaps you could try something like Joola Air Rossnet.
It's very light and not really all that bouncy from what I remember.
I've never played it right out of the package, but it's very very light.
Some boosters are only made to be put on the sponge, some are made to be put on both the topsheet and sponge.
They wear rubbers out more slowly from what I've seen, but some (like Falco Booster) give nearly all of the positive effects of speed glue nonetheless.
They really can vary, though.
EEII only gives about 20%-30% of regular speed glue's effect, Falco Booster gives 85%-95%.
I'm using Falco Booster now, and I don't really have any second thoughts about switching back.

I did a review of Actor, if you do a search it should come up.

Yes, what JSK said
The Actor I tried wasn't anything special.
Non-tacky topsheet, fast sponge.
40 deg palio/saviga is around the same speed category, maybe a tiny bit less.
I will say it was better than Nanocannon though.
True.
Got a sheet of Brio and find it pretty well made.
It's topsheet and sponge play quite consistently.
Basically a European style rubber.
Topsheet is fairly bouncy and neither tacky nor grippy, but can produce good amount of mechanical spin.
On Yasaka MLC (which is a fairly soft blade), this sheet feels soft/delicate on touch shots and can be fast with loops/smash.
It has good control as well.
Given it's play consistency, control can really just get better and better.
Overall, I'd say it's speed is about OFF.
Basically not terribly fast, but has the gears.

So far the most important negative aspect I found about the rubber is the user  I've always used chinese/japanese grippy rubbers and have gotten used to the "feel" of grippy rubbers when serving, pushing and looping.
Big strokes looping is definitely a no-no.
Really struggled to loop with comfort and confidence, although there were a few shots when I felt I had hit it right and produced nice mechanical spin from the rubber.
Well, ended up spending a couple of hours losing to a couple of players.
Although I felt like giving up on this rubber, I find this an opportunity to learn Euro loop technique ... Well, so, can someone give me a quick tip on Euro looping?
I think it's supposed to be compact?
More open blade surface?
Sort of like a salute?
yes, kind of like a salute, but make sure you're engaging the sponge and not just grazing the ball.
Had another tryout earlier.
Still finding looping pretty tough.
Fairly consistent during drills (e.g.
FH to FH), but very tough with varying ball speed, especially with 3rd balls.
Easy to hit the net (stroke too forward or too small upward) or go long when loop too hard.
Your main problem is almost certainly that you're not digging the ball into rubber consistantly, but are still brushing the ball.
Keep telling yourself to hit the ball into the rubber a bit more, and it will get better.

Top post has been updated:
Goo favoured SST729 2.2 vs Globe 999 National 2.2
Blade: Violin C
Reverse: Mark V 30
2 layers of FC.
Over the table
999 National had a sweet touch over the table, producing spinnier and faster pushes and flicks, at the slight expense of control due to the slightly softer and springier sponge.
The marginally harder surface of the SST729 produced excellent control shots, allowing both dropshots and flicks to be done relatively easily.
Close to the table
Here, the softer sponge of the 999 came into play.
Loops vs chop were more controlled than the SST729, while retaining approximately the same speeds.
Mid/Long distance
Long distance, the harder SST729 had marginally more power and loops tended to stretch, with less of a kick than the globe rubber.
999 arced more with higher spin and produced a vicious kick, especially on sidespin loops.
Speed
SST729
999 National
Spin
999 National
SST729
Control
999 National
SST729
*Top post updated*
DHS Skyline 2.
2 layers of FC.
Over the table
Skyline 2 has a surprisingly high amount of control over the table.
Definitely higher than SST729 and 999 Nat.
Spin seems good, possibly less than that of 999 Nat as the topsheet isn't quite as sticky.
Close to the table
I had some difficulty looping for a first few hits.
The throw felt considerably lower than 999 Nat and SST729.
As with SST729, well hit loops stretched low and flat with a visible kick.
With only 2 layers of FC, the sponge felt slightly softer than SST729 and very "corky", more than 999 Nat.
The feeling was less linear than the previous two with more of a "slow" gear and a "high" gear, with not much in between.
Looping vs chop was easy, but less so than the 999 Nat.
Mid/Long distance
Skyline 2 was noticeably slower than both of the others away from the table, with a larger arc.
Sidespin loops have more curve than SST729 and 999 Nat, but I'm not sure yet if it contained more spin than the 999 Nat.
I actually really like this rubber, possibly due to the corky feel.
For some reason it really reminds me of the sheet of Bty Tackifire C 1.9 Shoebox kindly donated to me, more so than the 999 Nat.
The 2.2mm sponge feels thinner somehow.
I might spend more time on it before I move on to the next one.
Great stuff silver, I appreciate your comments!
Right
Had to abandon my Skyline 2 during my training session today as I hadn't clamped it long enough.
It was doming something nasty on me and pulled itself off around 2cm right around the blade.
I cut and glued my sheet of Skyline 3 tonight as a quick substitute.
1 layer of 729 normal glue to prime, 1 layer of FC.
Before I start the usual format, I just want to say that this is the stickiest rubber I've used in a long time - stickier than 729.
I could pick up a ball (provided it wasn't powdery) and literally wave the bat around without dislodging the ball.
On to the review.
Over the table.
First impressions of Skyline 3 is that it is SLOW.
I was having a considerable amount of trouble flicking due to the speed and the amount of stickiness the rubber had - this was due to technique, as I'm used to a soft, fast rebound grippy rubber.
Pushing was definitely the spinniest so far.
Control was brilliant due to the speed (once I had gotten used to it).
Close to the table
Again, control here was brilliant.
I felt more like I was catching and throwing the ball back.
Throw was actually quite low (possibly due to the stick?
), but once I had adjusted to that, it was fine.
Loops kicked a bit, but the stickiness was reining in the speed too much.
This could be possibly better after the topsheet has been broken in a bit more.
Mid/Long Distance
In short: Too slow.
I'd need to revisit this with more glue.
This rubber feels more to me like a 3rd ball attack rubber than a rallying rubber.
Had another hit with Skyline 2 tonight.
2 layers of Mill chack, 36 hrs old.
Felt really hard.
Conclusion: Don't use LL
Good work Silver.
Skyline 3 seems like a winner for me but they all sound good.
Good to hear they all more dense compared to orange Hurricanes.
That would make it better.
I'm back to this.
On and off.
I tested TSP Triple 21 2.15mm black, primed with 2 layers of clean chack and glued with 2 layers of falco tempo.
First impressions of this rubber was good!
Soft topsheet combined with a soft sponge allowed for a mechanical spin approach to looping, but the moderately sticky rubber increased spin on serves dramatically and on the table play.
Speed was slower than that of the other, harder rubbers.
Slower than a harder topsheet sriver fx and cermet too.
Throw exhibited was very high.
Over the table:
Over the table was very spinny, with easily controlled flicks going on with less speed than the others.
The soft sponge allowed easy control of heavy "dig" pushes.
Close to the table:
Due to the high throw, looping vs both chop and top was a dream.
Definitely a looper's rubber; not so much an off-the-bounce blockers rubber.
Returns were possibly a bit high and slow, but the ability to place the ball whereever on the table more than made up for this in my opinion.
Mid/Long:
Counterloops carried more spin than speed, was easy enough to counterloop and had enough speed to trouble people.
Again, control was outstanding, especially on the loop to loop.
Conclusion:
Move over Juic 999 Elite Ultima!
I've found a new favourite sticky rubber!

Note: Still have to do my Hurricane 3 BS writeup.
Mini Conclusion Time
We've got two classes of rubbers here really.
Soft & Hard.
Hard class:
Tackifire C, Hurricane 2/3/BS Skyline 2/3, Friendship SST729 God Favoured, 999 National
Silver's pick: 999 National
If you're a Hurricane 3 user, get a sheet of 999 National.
It's got a better sponge than both regular and BS.
In a pinch you could grab a sheet of Butterfly Tackifire C instead of the 999 National, because it's pretty much a copy.
I suspect that the Tackifire C sheets are a bit more consistent from sheet to sheet, but costs 2x as much.
2nd place: Tackifire C
3rd place: Hurricane 2/3 BS
The hurricanes were nice, but the sponges could have been better.
Mounted on an OC, HH and WSC they were consistently slower than 999 National and Tackifire C.
What I didn't like: Skyline 3.
Huge stick and dead as a doormat, even with a heap of glue.
Soft class:
Tackifire C Soft, 999 Elite Ultima, Triple21
Silver's Pick: Tackifire C Soft.
this one plays more like a softer, corkier Tackifire C. I'd like to imagine that it's on top of the Sriver EL sponge, but I'm not sure.
999 EU is a bit easier to loop with and plays more euro-ish while Triple 21 is softer and easier to loop with again.
Tackifire C Soft's topsheet is harder than the latter two and better for quick attack.
I don't suppose you'll be trying out any of the Nittaku Hurricanes for this.

depends on how tacky/grippy a rubber is I suppose but in general you can create alot of more spin on the service with the tacky stuff but if your used to euro/jap rubbers it might be a pain adjusting all your strokes to real tacky rubbers.
I agree Magna is great to serve with, very tack with a very Euro Feel,
asr1990
I like the Juic 999 series stuff, as well as the Tackiness C for serving.

As a general rule the tackier rubbers do serve spinnier than the non tacky as they are able to apply a great deal of spin even at low ball pace whereas non tacky rubbers rely on the ball penetrating into the sponge to create spin.
practice....practice....practice
....or basically any tacky chinese rubber would be useful and of course you would have to loop the chinese way
metal monkey
In general it's much easier to generate heavy spin with a chinese style tacky rubber than it is with a non0tacky rubber.
Apart from that the slower and softer topsheets and sponges make it even easier.
Chinese rubber any day, or at least a Chinese topsheet.
Brush stroke spin is essential for a good serve, plus the ability to place the ball short.
Loopers rubber can achieve good spin but you have to hit the ball hard to achieve it, e.g.
Almana Sound.
You could argue that some of the Jap rubber such as BTY TSS is ok and thats fair comment but on the whole there is no better rubber for brush stroke spin then Chinese.
You have to choose between:
1. a soft (Desto F2 is great ...)european rubber
2. any chinese tacky rubber
All depends on spin at slow speed ...
